soln_description:
【Analysis and Solution】
$$
\begin{aligned}
10+9+8 \times 7 \div \square+6-5 \times 4-3 \times 2 & =1 \\
8 \times 7 \div \square & =1+3 \times 2+5 \times 4-6-9-10 \\
56 \div \square & =2 \\
\square & =28
\end{aligned}
$$
informal_statement:
【Question 1】
If $10+9+8 \times 7 \div \square+6-5 \times 4-3 \times 2=1$, then $\square=$ $\qquad$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 【Question 1】
If $10+9+8 \times 7 \div \square+6-5 \times 4-3 \times 2=1$, then $\square=$ $\qquad$. -/
theorem algebra_184184 (x : ℤ) : 10 + 9 + 8 * 7 / x + 6 - 5 * 4 - 3 * 2 = 1 ↔ x = 28 := by

soln_description:
Solution. We first prove this for odd numbers $n$. For these, modulo 4 we have $5^{n} \equiv 1^{n}=1$ and $3^{n} \equiv(-1)^{n} \equiv-1$, so $5^{n}-3^{n} \equiv 2 \bmod 4$. Therefore, if $n$ is odd, $a=1$. Since $b \geq 1$, the condition $a \leq b+3$ is satisfied.

Now assume that $n \equiv 2 \bmod 4$. Write $n=2 k$ with $k$ an odd positive integer. Note that $5^{2 k}-3^{2 k}=\left(5^{k}-3^{k}\right)\left(5^{k}+3^{k}\right)$. We have just shown that $5^{k}-3^{k}$ has exactly one factor 2, since $k$ is odd. We now examine $5^{k}+3^{k}$ modulo 16. For $m=1,2,3,4$, $5^{m}$ modulo 16 is congruent to $5,9,13,1$ respectively. Since $5^{4} \equiv 1 \bmod 16$, it follows that $5^{k} \equiv 5$ for all $k \equiv 1 \bmod 4$ and $5^{k} \equiv 13$ for all $k \equiv 3 \bmod 4$. For $m=1,2,3,4$, $3^{m}$ modulo 16 is congruent to $3,9,11,1$ respectively. Since $3^{4} \equiv 1 \bmod 16$, it follows that $3^{k} \equiv 3$ for all $k \equiv 1 \bmod 4$ and $3^{k} \equiv 11$ for all $k \equiv 3 \bmod 4$. In both cases, $5^{k}+3^{k} \equiv 5+3 \equiv 8 \bmod 16$ if $k \equiv 1 \bmod 4$ and $5^{k}+3^{k} \equiv 13+11=24 \equiv 8 \bmod 16$ if $k \equiv 3 \bmod 4$. In both cases, $5^{k}+3^{k}$ has exactly 3 factors 2.

We conclude that for $n \equiv 2 \bmod 4$, $a=4$. Since $b \geq 1$, the condition $a \leq b+3$ is satisfied.

We now prove by induction on $m$ that $a \leq b+3$ for all positive integers $n$ with exactly $m \geq 1$ factors 2. The base case is $m=1$, i.e., the case $n \equiv 2 \bmod 4$. We have already proven this.

Now let $m \geq 1$ and assume as the induction hypothesis that we have already shown $a \leq b+3$ for all numbers $n$ with exactly $m$ factors 2. Consider now a number $n$ with $m+1$ factors 2. We write $n=2 k$, where $k$ has exactly $m$ factors 2. Let $a(k)$ and $b(k)$ be the $a$ and $b$ corresponding to $k$, and $a(n)$ and $b(n)$ the $a$ and $b$ corresponding to $n$. The induction hypothesis states that $a(k) \leq b(k)+3$. We want to prove that $a(n) \leq b(n)+3$.

We have $5^{n}-3^{n}=5^{2 k}-3^{2 k}=\left(5^{k}-3^{k}\right)\left(5^{k}+3^{k}\right)$. Since $k$ is even (it has $m \geq 1$ factors 2), modulo 4 we have $5^{k}+3^{k} \equiv 1^{k}+(-1)^{k} \equiv 2 \bmod 4$. Therefore, $5^{k}+3^{k}$ has exactly one factor 2. Furthermore, $5^{k}-3^{k}$ has exactly $a(k)$ factors 2. Thus, $a(n)=a(k)+1$. We also know that $2^{b(k)} \leq k$ and $2^{b(k)+1}>k$, which implies that $2^{b(k)+1} \leq 2 k$ and $2^{b(k)+2}>2 k$. Therefore, $b(n)=b(k)+1$. We can now conclude: $a(n)=a(k)+1 \leq b(k)+3+1=b(n)+3$, completing the induction.

This proves that $a \leq b+3$ for all integers $n \geq 2$.
informal_statement:
Task 4. Let $n \geq 2$ be an integer. Let $a$ be the largest positive integer for which $2^{a} \mid 5^{n}-3^{n}$. Let $b$ be the largest positive integer for which $2^{b} \leq n$. Prove that $a \leq b+3$.

  

Translate the above text into English, please retain the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Task 4. Let $n \geq 2$ be an integer. Let $a$ be the largest positive integer for which $2^{a} \mid 5^{n}-3^{n}$. Let $b$ be the largest positive integer for which $2^{b} \leq n$. Prove that $a \leq b+3$.

  

Translate the above text into English, please retain the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly. -/
theorem number_theory_169570 (n : ℕ) (hn : 2 ≤ n) (a b : ℕ)
    (ha : IsGreatest {x | 0 < x ∧ 2 ^ x ∣ 5 ^ n - 3 ^ n} a)
    (hb : IsGreatest {x | 0 < x ∧ 2 ^ x ≤ n} b) :
    a ≤ b + 3 := by

soln_description:
[Proof 1] Let $p=1234567890 \cdot 10^{k}, n$ be a given positive integer, and $k$ be an integer such that $10^{k}>n$.

Then $p+1, p+2, \cdots, p+n$ are $n$ decimal numbers starting with 1234567890, and among these $n$ numbers, there must be one that is a multiple of $n$.
[Proof 2] Let $n$ be a given positive integer.
Also, let $A=\overline{1234567890}$
and denote $\underbrace{A A \cdots A}_{i \uparrow}=\underbrace{12345678901234567890 \cdots 1234567890}_{i=1}$,

Then in the sequence
$$
A, \quad A A, \cdots, \underbrace{A A \cdots A}_{n+1 \text { groups }}
$$
$$
\underbrace{A A \cdots A}_{\text {i groups }}-\underbrace{A A \cdots A}_{j \text { groups }}
$$

is a multiple of $n$, and this number is composed of all ten Arabic digits.
informal_statement:
$2 \cdot 36$ Prove that for every positive integer there exists a multiple of it, which contains all ten Arabic numerals.
(16th Putnam Mathematical Competition, 1956)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $2 \cdot 36$ Prove that for every positive integer there exists a multiple of it, which contains all ten Arabic numerals.
(16th Putnam Mathematical Competition, 1956) -/
theorem number_theory_221158 (n : ℕ) (hn : 0 < n) :
    ∃ m, n ∣ m ∧ ∀ i ∈ Finset.range 10, i ∈ Nat.digits 10 m := by

informal_statement: Given the set $S = \{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 40\}$, find a subset $T \subseteq S$ containing exactly $26$ elements such that the product of any two distinct elements in $T$ is never a perfect square. Additionally, prove that it is impossible to find a subset $T \subseteq S$ with $27$ elements that satisfies the same condition.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def S : Finset ℕ := Finset.Icc 1 40

/- Given the set $S = \{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 40\}$, find a subset $T \subseteq S$ containing exactly $26$ elements such that the product of any two distinct elements in $T$ is never a perfect square. Additionally, prove that it is impossible to find a subset $T \subseteq S$ with $27$ elements that satisfies the same condition. -/
theorem number_theory_5606 :
    ∃ T ⊆ S, T.card = 26 ∧ ∀ m ∈ T, ∀ n ∈ T, m ≠ n → ¬ ∃ k, k^2 = m * n ∧
    ¬∃ T ⊆ S, T.card = 27 ∧ ∀ m ∈ T, ∀ n ∈ T, m ≠ n → ¬ ∃ k, k^2 = m * n := by

soln_description:
Solution. $\log _{x} \frac{3}{8-2 x} \geq \log _{x} \frac{1}{x^{2}}$.

1) $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x>1, \\ \frac{3}{8-2 x} \geq \frac{1}{x^{2}}\end{array} \Leftrightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{l}x>1, \\ \frac{(x+2)\left(x-\frac{4}{3}\right)}{x-4} \leq 0\end{array} \Leftrightarrow \frac{4}{3} \leq x<4\right.\right.$

2) $\left\{\begin{array}{l}0<x<1, \\ \frac{3}{8-2 x} \leq \frac{1}{x^{2}}\end{array} \Leftrightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{l}0<x<1, \\ \frac{(x+2)\left(x-\frac{4}{3}\right)}{x-4} \geq 0\end{array} \Leftrightarrow 0<x<1\right.\right.$

Answer: $\quad x \in(0 ; 1) \cup\left[\frac{4}{3} ; 4\right)$.
informal_statement:
$9.270 \log _{x} \frac{3}{8-2 x} \geq-2$.

Translate the above text into English, please retain the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly.

$9.270 \log _{x} \frac{3}{8-2 x} \geq-2$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- $9.270 \log _{x} \frac{3}{8-2 x} \geq-2$.

Translate the above text into English, please retain the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly.

$9.270 \log _{x} \frac{3}{8-2 x} \geq-2$. -/
theorem inequalities_197572 (x : ℝ) (hx : x > 0 ∧ x ≠ 1 ∧ 8 - 2 * x > 0) :
    9.270 * logb x (3 / (8 - 2 * x)) ≥ -2 ↔ x ∈ Ioo 0 1 ∪ Ico (4 / 3) 4 := by

soln_description: $\begin{array}{l}\text { Prove } \quad \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{i}{2^{i}}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{i}{2^{i}}+\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{i}{2^{i}}\right) \\ =\frac{1}{2}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{i}{2^{i}}+\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{n+1-i}{2^{n+1-i}}\right) \\ =\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\frac{i}{2^{i}}+\frac{n+1-i}{2^{n+1-i}}\right) \\ \geqslant \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sqrt{\frac{i(n+1-i)}{2^{n+1}}} \\ \geqslant \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sqrt{\frac{n}{2^{n+1}}}=n \sqrt{\frac{n}{2^{n+1}}} .\end{array}$
informal_statement:
Given $n$ is a positive integer. Prove:
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{i}{2^{i}} \geqslant n \sqrt{\frac{n}{2^{n+1}}} \text {. }
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Given $n$ is a positive integer. Prove:
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{i}{2^{i}} \geqslant n \sqrt{\frac{n}{2^{n+1}}} \text {. }
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_309617 (n : ℕ) (hn : 0 < n) :
    ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, (i / 2^i : ℝ) ≥ n * sqrt (n / 2^(n + 1)) := by

soln_description:
From the given, we have $\sin ^{2} \alpha+\sin ^{2} \beta=\sin \alpha \cos \beta+\cos \alpha \sin \beta$, which means
$$
\sin \alpha(\sin \alpha-\cos \beta)=\sin \beta(\cos \alpha-\sin \beta) .
$$

If $\sin \alpha>\cos \beta$, then from (1) we get $\cos \alpha>\sin \beta$. Squaring both sides of these inequalities and adding them yields $\sin ^{2} \alpha+\cos ^{2} \alpha>\cos ^{2} \beta+\sin ^{2} \beta$, which simplifies to $1>1$, a contradiction.

Similarly, if $\sin \alpha<\cos \beta$, then from (1) we get $\cos \alpha<\sin \beta$, leading to $\sin ^{2} \alpha+\cos ^{2} \alpha<\cos ^{2} \beta+\sin ^{2} \beta$, which is also a contradiction.
Therefore, we have $\sin \alpha=\cos \beta$, which means $\cos \left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\alpha\right)=\cos \beta$, hence $\frac{\pi}{2}-\alpha=\beta$, or $\alpha+\beta=\frac{\pi}{2}$.
informal_statement: 2.2.19 ** Two acute angles $\alpha$ and $\beta$ satisfy the equation $\sin ^{2} \alpha+\sin ^{2} \beta=\sin (\alpha+\beta)$, prove that $\alpha+\beta=\frac{\pi}{2}$.
informal_proof:
Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be two real numbers such that $0 < \alpha < \frac{\pi}{2}$ and $0 < \beta < \frac{\pi}{2}$. We are given the equation $\sin^2 \alpha + \sin^2 \beta = \sin(\alpha + \beta)$.

First, we use the angle addition formula for sine, which states that $\sin(\alpha + \beta) = \sin \alpha \cos \beta + \cos \alpha \sin \beta$. Substituting this into the given equation, we obtain:
$$ \sin^2 \alpha + \sin^2 \beta = \sin \alpha \cos \beta + \cos \alpha \sin \beta $$
We rearrange this equation to:
$$ \sin^2 \alpha - \sin \alpha \cos \beta + \sin^2 \beta - \cos \alpha \sin \beta = 0 $$
This can be factored as:
$$ \sin \alpha (\sin \alpha - \cos \beta) + \sin \beta (\sin \beta - \cos \alpha) = 0 \quad (*) $$

Now, we proceed by considering three cases for the sum $\alpha + \beta$:

**Case 1: Assume $\alpha + \beta < \frac{\pi}{2}$**

From the assumption $\alpha + \beta < \frac{\pi}{2}$, we can derive two auxiliary inequalities:
1.  $\beta < \frac{\pi}{2} - \alpha$
2.  $\alpha < \frac{\pi}{2} - \beta$

Since $0 < \alpha < \frac{\pi}{2}$ and $0 < \beta < \frac{\pi}{2}$, we know that $\sin \alpha$, $\cos \alpha$, $\sin \beta$, and $\cos \beta$ are all strictly positive. Also, the sine function is strictly increasing on the interval $(0, \frac{\pi}{2})$.

Considering the first auxiliary inequality $\beta < \frac{\pi}{2} - \alpha$:
Since $0 < \beta < \frac{\pi}{2} - \alpha < \frac{\pi}{2}$ (because $0 < \alpha < \frac{\pi}{2}$ implies $0 < \frac{\pi}{2} - \alpha < \frac{\pi}{2}$), we can apply the strict monotonicity of sine:
$$ \sin \beta < \sin\left(\frac{\pi}{2} - \alpha\right) $$
Using the identity $\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{2} - x\right) = \cos x$, we get:
$$ \sin \beta < \cos \alpha $$

Similarly, considering the second auxiliary inequality $\alpha < \frac{\pi}{2} - \beta$:
Since $0 < \alpha < \frac{\pi}{2} - \beta < \frac{\pi}{2}$, we apply the strict monotonicity of sine:
$$ \sin \alpha < \sin\left(\frac{\pi}{2} - \beta\right) $$
Using the identity $\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{2} - x\right) = \cos x$, we get:
$$ \sin \alpha < \cos \beta $$

Now, let's look at equation $(*)$:
$$ \sin \alpha (\sin \alpha - \cos \beta) + \sin \beta (\sin \beta - \cos \alpha) = 0 $$
From $\sin \alpha < \cos \beta$, it follows that $\sin \alpha - \cos \beta < 0$.
From $\sin \beta < \cos \alpha$, it follows that $\sin \beta - \cos \alpha < 0$.
Since $\sin \alpha > 0$ and $\sin \beta > 0$:
The term $\sin \alpha (\sin \alpha - \cos \beta)$ is a product of a positive number and a negative number, so it is strictly negative.
The term $\sin \beta (\sin \beta - \cos \alpha)$ is also a product of a positive number and a negative number, so it is strictly negative.
The sum of two strictly negative numbers cannot be zero. Thus, equation $(*)$ becomes the sum of two negative numbers equaling zero, which is a contradiction.
Therefore, the assumption $\alpha + \beta < \frac{\pi}{2}$ must be false.

**Case 2: Assume $\alpha + \beta \geq \frac{\pi}{2}$**

This case is further divided into two subcases:

**Subcase 2a: Assume $\alpha + \beta > \frac{\pi}{2}$**

From the assumption $\alpha + \beta > \frac{\pi}{2}$, we can derive two auxiliary inequalities:
1.  $\beta > \frac{\pi}{2} - \alpha$
2.  $\alpha > \frac{\pi}{2} - \beta$

Similar to Case 1, since $0 < \alpha < \frac{\pi}{2}$ and $0 < \beta < \frac{\pi}{2}$, all sines and cosines are positive, and sine is strictly increasing on $(0, \frac{\pi}{2})$.

Considering the first auxiliary inequality $\beta > \frac{\pi}{2} - \alpha$:
Since $0 < \frac{\pi}{2} - \alpha < \beta < \frac{\pi}{2}$, we apply the strict monotonicity of sine:
$$ \sin\left(\frac{\pi}{2} - \alpha\right) < \sin \beta $$
Using the identity $\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{2} - x\right) = \cos x$, we get:
$$ \cos \alpha < \sin \beta $$

Similarly, considering the second auxiliary inequality $\alpha > \frac{\pi}{2} - \beta$:
Since $0 < \frac{\pi}{2} - \beta < \alpha < \frac{\pi}{2}$, we apply the strict monotonicity of sine:
$$ \sin\left(\frac{\pi}{2} - \beta\right) < \sin \alpha $$
Using the identity $\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{2} - x\right) = \cos x$, we get:
$$ \cos \beta < \sin \alpha $$

Now, let's look at equation $(*)$:
$$ \sin \alpha (\sin \alpha - \cos \beta) + \sin \beta (\sin \beta - \cos \alpha) = 0 $$
From $\sin \alpha > \cos \beta$, it follows that $\sin \alpha - \cos \beta > 0$.
From $\sin \beta > \cos \alpha$, it follows that $\sin \beta - \cos \alpha > 0$.
Since $\sin \alpha > 0$ and $\sin \beta > 0$:
The term $\sin \alpha (\sin \alpha - \cos \beta)$ is a product of two positive numbers, so it is strictly positive.
The term $\sin \beta (\sin \beta - \cos \alpha)$ is also a product of two positive numbers, so it is strictly positive.
The sum of two strictly positive numbers cannot be zero. Thus, equation $(*)$ becomes the sum of two positive numbers equaling zero, which is a contradiction.
Therefore, the assumption $\alpha + \beta > \frac{\pi}{2}$ must be false.

**Subcase 2b: Assume $\alpha + \beta = \frac{\pi}{2}$**

This subcase is consistent with our deductions. Since both Case 1 ($\alpha + \beta < \frac{\pi}{2}$) and Subcase 2a ($\alpha + \beta > \frac{\pi}{2}$) lead to contradictions, the only remaining possibility is that $\alpha + \beta = \frac{\pi}{2}$.

Therefore, we have proven that $\alpha + \beta = \frac{\pi}{2}$.

$\square$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2.2.19 ** Two acute angles $\alpha$ and $\beta$ satisfy the equation $\sin ^{2} \alpha+\sin ^{2} \beta=\sin (\alpha+\beta)$, prove that $\alpha+\beta=\frac{\pi}{2}$. -/
theorem algebra_131074 (α β : ℝ) (h₀ : α ∈ Set.Ioo 0 (Real.pi / 2)) (h₁ : β ∈ Set.Ioo 0 (Real.pi / 2))
    (h₂ : Real.sin α ^ 2 + Real.sin β ^ 2 = Real.sin (α + β)) : α + β = Real.pi / 2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_131074 (α β : ℝ) (h₀ : α ∈ Set.Ioo 0 (Real.pi / 2)) (h₁ : β ∈ Set.Ioo 0 (Real.pi / 2))
    (h₂ : Real.sin α ^ 2 + Real.sin β ^ 2 = Real.sin (α + β)) : α + β = Real.pi / 2 := by
  rw [Set.mem_Ioo] at h₀ h₁
  have h3 : Real.sin (α + β) = Real.sin α * Real.cos β + Real.cos α * Real.sin β := by
    rw [Real.sin_add]
  rw [h3] at h₂
  by_cases h : α + β < Real.pi / 2
  · -- Assume that α + β < π/2
    have h4 : β < Real.pi / 2 - α := by linarith [h]
    have h5 : Real.sin β < Real.cos α := by
      have h8 : Real.sin β < Real.sin (Real.pi / 2 - α) := by
        apply Real.sin_lt_sin_of_lt_of_le_pi_div_two
        all_goals
          nlinarith [h₀.1, Real.pi_pos, h₀.2, h₁.1, h₁.2]
          <;> nlinarith [h4, h₀.1, Real.pi_pos, h₀.2, h₁.1, h₁.2, Real.sin_pos_of_pos_of_lt_pi h₀.1 (show α < Real.pi by linarith [h₀.2, Real.pi_pos]), Real.sin_pos_of_pos_of_lt_pi h₁.1 (show β < Real.pi by linarith [h₁.2, Real.pi_pos]), Real.sin_pi_div_two]
      have h8' : Real.sin (Real.pi / 2 - α) = Real.cos α := by
        rw [Real.sin_pi_div_two_sub]
      linarith [h8, h8']
      all_goals nlinarith
    have h10 : Real.sin α < Real.cos β := by
      have h11 : Real.sin α < Real.sin (Real.pi / 2 - β) := by
        apply Real.sin_lt_sin_of_lt_of_le_pi_div_two
        all_goals
          nlinarith [h₀.1, Real.pi_pos, h₀.2, h₁.1, h₁.2]
          <;> nlinarith [h4, h₀.1, Real.pi_pos, h₀.2, h₁.1, h₁.2, Real.sin_pos_of_pos_of_lt_pi h₀.1 (show α < Real.pi by linarith [h₀.2, Real.pi_pos]), Real.sin_pos_of_pos_of_lt_pi h₁.1 (show β < Real.pi by linarith [h₁.2, Real.pi_pos]), Real.sin_pi_div_two]
      have h12 : Real.sin (Real.pi / 2 - β) = Real.cos β := by
        rw [Real.sin_pi_div_two_sub]
      linarith [h12, h11]
      all_goals nlinarith
    nlinarith [Real.sin_pos_of_pos_of_lt_pi (show 0 < α by linarith [h₀.1]) (show α < Real.pi by linarith [h₀.2, Real.pi_pos]), Real.sin_pos_of_pos_of_lt_pi (show 0 < β by linarith [h₁.1]) (show β < Real.pi by linarith [h₁.2, Real.pi_pos]), Real.sin_sq_add_cos_sq α, Real.sin_sq_add_cos_sq β, Real.sin_sq_add_cos_sq (Real.pi / 2 - α), Real.sin_sq_add_cos_sq (Real.pi / 2 - β), Real.pi_pos, Real.sin_pi_div_two]
  · -- Assume that α + β ≥ π/2
    by_cases h' : α + β > Real.pi / 2
    · -- Assume that α + β > π/2
      have h6 : β > Real.pi / 2 - α := by linarith [h']
      have h7 : Real.sin β > Real.cos α := by
        have h8 : Real.sin β > Real.sin (Real.pi / 2 - α) := by
          apply Real.sin_lt_sin_of_lt_of_le_pi_div_two
          all_goals
            nlinarith [h₀.1, Real.pi_pos, h₀.2, h₁.1, h₁.2]
            <;> nlinarith [h6, h₀.1, Real.pi_pos, h₀.2, h₁.1, h₁.2, Real.sin_pos_of_pos_of_lt_pi h₀.1 (show α < Real.pi by linarith [h₀.2, Real.pi_pos]), Real.sin_pos_of_pos_of_lt_pi h₁.1 (show β < Real.pi by linarith [h₁.2, Real.pi_pos]), Real.sin_pi_div_two]
        have h8' : Real.sin (Real.pi / 2 - α) = Real.cos α := by
          rw [Real.sin_pi_div_two_sub]
        linarith [h8, h8']
        all_goals nlinarith
      have h12 : Real.sin α > Real.cos β := by
        have h11 : Real.sin α > Real.sin (Real.pi / 2 - β) := by
          apply Real.sin_lt_sin_of_lt_of_le_pi_div_two
          all_goals
            nlinarith [h₀.1, Real.pi_pos, h₀.2, h₁.1, h₁.2]
            <;> nlinarith [h6, h₀.1, Real.pi_pos, h₀.2, h₁.1, h₁.2, Real.sin_pos_of_pos_of_lt_pi h₀.1 (show α < Real.pi by linarith [h₀.2, Real.pi_pos]), Real.sin_pos_of_pos_of_lt_pi h₁.1 (show β < Real.pi by linarith [h₁.2, Real.pi_pos]), Real.sin_pi_div_two]
        have h13 : Real.sin (Real.pi / 2 - β) = Real.cos β := by
          rw [Real.sin_pi_div_two_sub]
        linarith [h13, h11]
        all_goals nlinarith
      nlinarith [Real.sin_pos_of_pos_of_lt_pi (show 0 < α by linarith [h₀.1]) (show α < Real.pi by linarith [h₀.2, Real.pi_pos]), Real.sin_pos_of_pos_of_lt_pi (show 0 < β by linarith [h₁.1]) (show β < Real.pi by linarith [h₁.2, Real.pi_pos]), Real.sin_sq_add_cos_sq α, Real.sin_sq_add_cos_sq β, Real.sin_sq_add_cos_sq (Real.pi / 2 - α), Real.sin_sq_add_cos_sq (Real.pi / 2 - β), Real.pi_pos, Real.sin_pi_div_two]
    · -- Assume that α + β = π/2
      linarith

informal_statement: Solve the linear equation $x-\frac{2x}{5}=\frac{7+x}{4}$.
informal_proof:
To prove the equality of the sets, we must show that an arbitrary real number \(x\) belongs to the set \(\{x \in \mathbb{R} \mid x - \frac{2x}{5} = \frac{7+x}{4}\}\) if and only if \(x\) belongs to the set \(\{5\}\). This reduces to proving the logical equivalence:
\[
x - \frac{2x}{5} = \frac{7+x}{4} \quad \iff \quad x = 5
\]
We prove this equivalence by showing both implications:

**Part 1: Assume \(x - \frac{2x}{5} = \frac{7+x}{4}\) and prove \(x = 5\).**
Let's assume the equation:
\[
x - \frac{2x}{5} = \frac{7+x}{4}
\]
First, simplify the left side of the equation:
\[
x - \frac{2x}{5} = \frac{5x}{5} - \frac{2x}{5} = \frac{3x}{5}
\]
So the equation becomes:
\[
\frac{3x}{5} = \frac{7+x}{4}
\]
To eliminate the denominators, multiply both sides by the least common multiple of 5 and 4, which is 20:
\[
20 \cdot \frac{3x}{5} = 20 \cdot \frac{7+x}{4}
\]
\[
4 \cdot 3x = 5 \cdot (7+x)
\]
\[
12x = 35 + 5x
\]
Now, gather the terms involving \(x\) on one side by subtracting \(5x\) from both sides:
\[
12x - 5x = 35
\]
\[
7x = 35
\]
Finally, divide by 7 to solve for \(x\):
\[
x = \frac{35}{7}
\]
\[
x = 5
\]
This completes the first part of the proof.

**Part 2: Assume \(x = 5\) and prove \(x - \frac{2x}{5} = \frac{7+x}{4}\).**
Let's assume \(x = 5\). We substitute this value into both sides of the original equation and verify that they are equal.

Substitute \(x=5\) into the left side of the equation:
\[
5 - \frac{2 \cdot 5}{5} = 5 - \frac{10}{5} = 5 - 2 = 3
\]
Substitute \(x=5\) into the right side of the equation:
\[
\frac{7+5}{4} = \frac{12}{4} = 3
\]
Since both sides evaluate to 3, we have \(3 = 3\), which is true. This confirms that if \(x=5\), the equation holds.

Since we have shown both implications, the equivalence \(x - \frac{2x}{5} = \frac{7+x}{4} \iff x = 5\) is established. Therefore, the set of solutions to the equation is indeed \(\{5\}\).

This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Solve the linear equation $x-\frac{2x}{5}=\frac{7+x}{4}$. -/
theorem algebra_5567 : {x : ℝ | x - 2 * x / 5 = (7 + x) / 4} = {5} := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_5567 : {x : ℝ | x - 2 * x / 5 = (7 + x) / 4} = {5} := by
  ext x
  simp only [Set.mem_setOf_eq, Set.mem_singleton_iff]
  constructor
  · -- Assume x - 2x/5 = (7 + x)/4, prove x = 5
    intro h
    linarith
  · -- Assume x = 5, prove x - 2x/5 = (7 + x)/4
    intro h
    rw [h]
    norm_num

import Mathlib

soln_description:
For $47$ to be written as the sum of two [integers](https://artofproblemsolving.com/wiki/index.php/Integer), one must be [odd](https://artofproblemsolving.com/wiki/index.php/Odd) and the other must be even.  There is only one [even](https://artofproblemsolving.com/wiki/index.php/Even) prime, namely $2$, so one of the numbers must be $2$, making the other $45$.
However, $45$ is not prime, so there are no ways to write $47$ as the sum of two primes $\rightarrow \boxed{\text{A}}$.
informal_statement:
In how many ways can $47$ be written as the [sum](https://artofproblemsolving.com/wiki/index.php/Sum) of two [primes](https://artofproblemsolving.com/wiki/index.php/Prime_number)?
$\text{(A)}\ 0 \qquad \text{(B)}\ 1 \qquad \text{(C)}\ 2 \qquad \text{(D)}\ 3 \qquad \text{(E)}\ \text{more than 3}$
informal_proof:
We want to determine the number of ways $47$ can be expressed as the sum of two prime numbers. This is equivalent to finding the natural number cardinality of the set $S = \{(p, q) : \mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N} \mid p \text{ is prime } \land q \text{ is prime } \land p + q = 47\}$.

The proof proceeds in two main steps:

1.  **Prove that the set $S$ is empty.**
    Let's assume, for the sake of contradiction, that there exists a pair $(p, q)$ in $S$. This means that $p$ is a prime number, $q$ is a prime number, and their sum $p + q = 47$.

    From the condition $p + q = 47$, and knowing that $p$ and $q$ are natural numbers (thus non-negative), it logically follows that $p \leq 47$ and $q \leq 47$.

    Now, we employ an exhaustive case analysis for all possible integer values of $p$ and $q$ within their derived bounds. We systematically consider every natural number $p$ from $0$ to $47$. For each chosen value of $p$, we then consider every natural number $q$ from $0$ to $47$.

    For each specific pair $(p_{\text{val}}, q_{\text{val}})$ generated by this exhaustive process, we check the three conditions required for the pair to be in $S$:
    *   Is $p_{\text{val}}$ a prime number?
    *   Is $q_{\text{val}}$ a prime number?
    *   Is their sum $p_{\text{val}} + q_{\text{val}}$ equal to $47$?

    This systematic verification reveals that for every single combination of $(p_{\text{val}}, q_{\text{val}})$ where $0 \leq p_{\text{val}} \leq 47$ and $0 \leq q_{\text{val}} \leq 47$, at least one of the three conditions is violated, leading to a contradiction. Here are a few illustrative examples:
    *   If $p_{\text{val}} = 1$: $1$ is not a prime number, so the condition "$p_{\text{val}}$ is prime" fails.
    *   If $p_{\text{val}} = 2$: $2$ is prime. For $p_{\text{val}} + q_{\text{val}} = 47$, we must have $q_{\text{val}} = 45$. However, $45$ is not a prime number (it is divisible by $3$, $5$, etc.), so the condition "$q_{\text{val}}$ is prime" fails.
    *   If $p_{\text{val}} = 3$: $3$ is prime. For $p_{\text{val}} + q_{\text{val}} = 47$, we must have $q_{\text{val}} = 44$. However, $44$ is not a prime number.
    *   This pattern continues for all possible prime values of $p_{\text{val}}$. For example, if $p_{\text{val}}$ is an odd prime, then for $p_{\text{val}} + q_{\text{val}} = 47$ (which is odd), $q_{\text{val}}$ must be an even number. The only even prime number is $2$. Thus, if $p_{\text{val}}$ is an odd prime, $q_{\text{val}}$ must be $2$. This leads to $p_{\text{val}} + 2 = 47$, so $p_{\text{val}} = 45$. But $45$ is not prime.
    *   More generally, if $p_{\text{val}}$ is a prime other than $2$, it is odd. If $q_{\text{val}}$ is also an odd prime, then their sum $p_{\text{val}} + q_{\text{val}}$ would be even. However, $47$ is odd. This means that if $p$ and $q$ are both prime and sum to $47$, one of them must be $2$. Without loss of generality, let $p=2$. Then $2+q=47$, which implies $q=45$. Since $45$ is not prime (it is divisible by $3$ and $5$), this case also leads to a contradiction.

    Since every possible pair $(p, q)$ either fails the primality test for $p$, the primality test for $q$, or the sum condition $p+q=47$, our initial assumption that such a pair exists must be false. Therefore, the set $S$ is empty.

2.  **Conclude the cardinality is zero.**
    Having established that $S = \emptyset$, we substitute this fact into the original statement. The natural number cardinality of the empty set is, by definition, $0$.
    Thus, $\left|\{(p, q) : \mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N} \mid p \text{ is prime } \land q \text{ is prime } \land p + q = 47\}\right| = |\emptyset| = 0$.

Therefore, there are $0$ ways to write $47$ as the sum of two prime numbers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- In how many ways can $47$ be written as the [sum](https://artofproblemsolving.com/wiki/index.php/Sum) of two [primes](https://artofproblemsolving.com/wiki/index.php/Prime_number)?
$\text{(A)}\ 0 \qquad \text{(B)}\ 1 \qquad \text{(C)}\ 2 \qquad \text{(D)}\ 3 \qquad \text{(E)}\ \text{more than 3}$ -/
theorem number_theory_97060 :
    {(p, q) : ℕ × ℕ | p.Prime ∧ q.Prime ∧ p + q = 47}.ncard = 0 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_97060 :
    {(p, q) : ℕ × ℕ | p.Prime ∧ q.Prime ∧ p + q = 47}.ncard = 0 := by
  have h1 : {(p, q) : ℕ × ℕ | p.Prime ∧ q.Prime ∧ p + q = 47} = ∅ := by
    ext ⟨p, q⟩
    simp
    intro hp hq hsum
    have h2 : p ≤ 47 := by linarith
    have h3 : q ≤ 47 := by linarith
    interval_cases p <;> interval_cases q
    <;> norm_num at hp hq hsum
    <;> all_goals
      contradiction
  rw [h1]
  simp

informal_statement:
Prove that the function \[ f(
u)= \int_1^{ rac{1}{
u}}  rac{dx}{\sqrt{(x^2-1)(1-
u^2x^2)}}\]
(where the positive value of the square root is taken) is monotonically decreasing in the interval $ 0<
