\left\lfloor \frac{2^{2j+1}}{3} \right\rfloor + \left\lfloor \frac{2^{2j+2}}{3} \right\rfloor = 2^{2j+1} - 1
$$
So the sum of these 500 pairs becomes:
$$
\sum_{j=0}^{499} (2^{2j+1} - 1)
$$
This sum can be split into two parts:
$$
\left( \sum_{j=0}^{499} 2^{2j+1} \right) - \left( \sum_{j=0}^{499} 1 \right)
$$

**Step 6: Evaluate each part of the split sum.**
The second part is simply \( \sum_{j=0}^{499} 1 = 500 \).

The first part is a geometric series:
$$
\sum_{j=0}^{499} 2^{2j+1} = 2^1 + 2^3 + 2^5 + \cdots + 2^{999}
$$
This is a geometric series with:
*   First term \( a = 2^1 = 2 \).
*   Common ratio \( r = 2^2 = 4 \).
*   Number of terms \( n = 500 \).

The sum of a geometric series is given by \( a \frac{r^n - 1}{r - 1} \).
Plugging in the values:
$$
2 \cdot \frac{4^{500} - 1}{4 - 1} = 2 \cdot \frac{(2^2)^{500} - 1}{3} = 2 \cdot \frac{2^{1000} - 1}{3} = \frac{2^{1001} - 2}{3}
$$

**Step 7: Combine the results.**
The total sum is the result of the geometric series minus the sum of ones:
$$
\frac{2^{1001} - 2}{3} - 500
$$
This matches the right-hand side of the theorem statement.

The final result is:
$$
\sum_{i \in \text{Finset.range } 1001} \left\lfloor \frac{2^i}{3} \right\rfloor = \frac{2^{1001} - 2}{3} - 500
$$
The proof is complete.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 10.1. Summation
$$
\left[\frac{1}{3}\right]+\left[\frac{2}{3}\right]+\left[\frac{2^{2}}{3}\right]+\left[\frac{2^{3}}{3}\right]+\cdots+\left[\frac{2^{1000}}{3}\right]
$$ -/
theorem number_theory_327537 : ∑ i ∈ Finset.range 1001, ⌊(2 ^ i : ℝ) / 3⌋ = (2 ^ 1001 - 2) / 3 - 500 := by

soln_description:
Solution. The given expression can be transformed as follows:

$$
a=\frac{4 b-5}{b-2}=\frac{4(b-2)+8-5}{b-2}=\frac{4(b-2)}{b-2}+\frac{3}{b-2}=4+\frac{3}{b-2}
$$

The number $a$ will be an integer if and only if $\frac{3}{b-2}$ is an integer, which is true if and only if $b-2$ is a divisor of 3, i.e., if and only if $b-2 \in\{1,-1,3,-3\}$.

Accordingly, there are four possibilities, namely:

- For $b-2=1$ we get $b=3, a=4+3=7$,
- For $b-2=-1$ we get $b=1, a=4-3=1$,
- For $b-2=3$ we get $b=5, a=4+1=5$ and
- For $b-2=-3$ we get $b=-1, a=4-1=3$.

The required pairs are: $(7,3),(1,1),(5,5)$ and $(3,-1)$.
informal_statement: Problem 2. Find all pairs of integers $(a, b)$ for which $a=\frac{4 b-5}{b-2}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Problem 2. Find all pairs of integers $(a, b)$ for which $a=\frac{4 b-5}{b-2}$ -/
theorem algebra_237409 (a b : ℤ) (h : a = (4 * b - 5) / (b - 2)) :
    (a = 7 ∧ b = 3) ∨ (a = 1 ∧ b = 1) ∨ (a = 5 ∧ b = 5) ∨ (a = 3 ∧ b = -1) := by

soln_description:
The number of days in a month varies between 28 and 31, meaning that every month has at least 4 Sundays, but no month has more than 5. A year consists of $365=52 \cdot 7+1$ days, or in a leap year, $366=52 \cdot 7+2$ days, so there are 52 or 53 Sundays in a year.

Each of the twelve months thus contains at least 4 Sundays. Beyond the 48 Sundays, the remaining 4 or 5 Sundays must fall in different months, as no month can have 6 Sundays.

This means that in a year, there can be at most five months with 5 Sundays. This occurs in years with 53 Sundays, i.e., when the first day of the year is a Sunday, or in a leap year when the first day is a Saturday or Sunday.

Sziveri János (Budapest, I. István Gymn., I. o. t.)
informal_statement: What is the maximum number of months in a year that can have five Sundays?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- What is the maximum number of months in a year that can have five Sundays? -/
theorem number_theory_159682 :
    IsGreatest {k | ∃ m, k = {i | i ∈ Finset.range 12 ∧ (m + i) % 7 = 0}.ncard} 5 := by

soln_description:
$$\begin{array}{l}
10 . \\
\text { (1) }\left(7 x^{3}(y+z)+x^{2}\left(9 y^{2}+16 y z+9 z^{2}\right)+11 x y z(y+z)\right. \\
\left.+2 y^{2} z^{2}\right)^{2}-48 x(x+y)(x+z)(x+y+z)(y z+z x+x y)^{2} \\
=\frac{x^{6}(y-z)^{2}\left(y^{2}+6 y z+z^{2}\right)}{(y+z)^{2}} \\
+\frac{2 x^{5}(y-z)^{2}\left(3 z^{2}+8 y z+3 y^{2}\right)\left(5 z^{2}+6 y z+5 y^{2}\right)}{(y+z)^{3}} \\
+\frac{x^{4}(y-z)^{2}\left(33 y^{6}+208 y^{5} z+531 y^{4} z^{2}+696 y^{3} z^{3}+531 y^{2} z^{4}+208 y z^{5}+33 z^{6}\right)}{(y+z)^{4}} \\
+\frac{2 x^{3} y z(y-z)^{2}\left(27 y^{6}+166 y^{5} z+437 y^{4} z^{2}+660 y^{3} z^{3}+437 y^{2} z^{4}+166 y z^{5}+27 z^{6}\right)}{(y+z)^{5}} \\
+\frac{7 x^{2} y^{2} z^{2}(y-z)^{4}\left(3 y^{4}+20 y^{3} z+50 y^{2} z^{2}+20 y z^{3}+3 z^{4}\right)}{2(y+z)^{6}} \\
+\frac{y^{2} z^{2}(y-z)^{2}\left(y^{2}+6 y z+z^{2}\right)\left(y^{4}+4 y^{3} z+22 y^{2} z^{2}+4 y z^{3}+z^{4}\right)\left(5 x^{2}(y+z)^{2}-8 x y z(y+z)+8 y^{2} z^{2}\right)}{2(y+z)^{8}} \\
+\frac{16 y^{2} z^{2}(2 y z+z x+x y)^{2}(2 y z-x y-z x)^{4}}{(y+z)^{8}} \geqslant 0 \Rightarrow \\
\sum_{\text {cyc }} z \sqrt{\frac{x}{1-x}}=\sum_{\text {cyc }} z \sqrt{\frac{x}{y+z}} \\
\leqslant \sum_{\text {cyc }} \frac{z\left(7 x^{3}(y+z)+x^{2}\left(9 y^{2}+16 y z+9 z^{2}\right)+11 x y z(y+z)+2 y^{2} z^{2}\right)}{4(y z+z x+x y) \sqrt{3(y+z)(z+x)(x+y)(x+y+z)}} \\
=\frac{9}{4} \sqrt{\frac{(y+z)(z+x)(x+y)}{3(x+y+z)}}=\frac{3 \sqrt{3(1-x)(1-y)(1-z)}}{4} .
\end{array}$$
(2) Using weighted power means and the conclusion from (1), we get
$$\sum_{\mathrm{cyc}} z \sqrt[3]{\frac{x}{y+z}} \leqslant\left(\sum_{\mathrm{cyc}} z \sqrt{\frac{x}{y+z}}\right)^{\frac{2}{3}} \leqslant \frac{3}{2} \sqrt[3]{\frac{(y+z)(z+x)(x+y)}{2}} .$$

In fact, there are two stronger inequalities:
$$\begin{aligned}
& z \sqrt{\frac{x}{y+z}}+x \sqrt{\frac{y}{z+x}}+y \sqrt{\frac{z}{x+y}} \\
\leqslant & \sqrt{\frac{25\left(x^{2} y+x^{2} z+y^{2} z+y^{2} x+z^{2} x+z^{2} y\right)+66 x y z}{16(x+y+z)}} \\
& z \sqrt[3]{\frac{x}{y+z}}+x \sqrt[3]{\frac{y}{z+x}}+y \sqrt[3]{\frac{z}{x+y}} \\
\leqslant & \frac{\sqrt[3]{9\left(x^{2} y+x^{2} z+y^{2} z+y^{2} z+z^{2} x+z^{2} y+6 x y z\right)}}{2}
\end{aligned}$$

for all positive real numbers $x, y, z$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 10. Let positive real numbers $x, y, z$ satisfy $x+y+z=1$. Prove:
(1) $\frac{x}{\sqrt{\frac{1}{y}-1}}+\frac{y}{\sqrt{\frac{1}{z}-1}}+\frac{z}{\sqrt{\frac{1}{x}-1}} \leqslant \frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{4} \sqrt{(1-x)(1-y)(1-z)}$;
(2) $\frac{x}{\sqrt[3]{\frac{1}{y}-1}}+\frac{y}{\sqrt[3]{\frac{1}{z}-1}}+\frac{z}{\sqrt[3]{\frac{1}{x}-1}} \leqslant \frac{3}{2 \sqrt[3]{2}} \sqrt[3]{(1-x)(1-y)(1-z)}$. -/
theorem inequalities_602636 (x y z : ℝ) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) (hz : 0 < z)
    (hsum : x + y + z = 1) :
    x / sqrt ((1 / y) - 1) + y / sqrt ((1 / z) - 1) +
    z / sqrt ((1 / x) - 1) ≤
    3 * sqrt 3 / 4 * sqrt ((1 - x) * (1 - y) * (1 - z)) ∧
    x / ((1 / y) - 1) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 3) +
    y / ((1 / z) - 1) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 3) +
    z / ((1 / x) - 1) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 3) ≤
    3 / (2 * (2 ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 3))) * ((1 - x) * (1 - y) * (1 - z)) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 3) := by

soln_description:
1. Given the equation \( x^2 + xy - y = k^2 \), we start by rearranging it to isolate \( y \):
   \[
   x^2 + xy - y = k^2 \implies y(x - 1) = k^2 - x^2
   \]
   Therefore, we can express \( y \) as:
   \[
   y = \frac{k^2 - x^2}{x - 1}
   \]

2. Since \( y \) is a natural number, \( x - 1 \) must divide \( k^2 - x^2 \). We can factorize \( k^2 - x^2 \) as:
   \[
   k^2 - x^2 = (k - x)(k + x)
   \]
   Thus, \( x - 1 \) must divide the product \( (k - x)(k + x) \).

3. Let \( x - 1 = b_1 b_2 \) where \( b_1 \mid (k - x) \) and \( b_2 \mid (k + x) \). This implies:
   \[
   k - x = b_1 m \quad \text{and} \quad k + x = b_2 n
   \]
   for some integers \( m \) and \( n \).

4. We need to show that \( x + y + 1 \) is a composite number. Substituting \( y \) from step 1, we get:
   \[
   x + y + 1 = x + \frac{k^2 - x^2}{x - 1} + 1
   \]
   Simplifying the expression:
   \[
   x + y + 1 = x + \frac{k^2 - x^2}{x - 1} + 1 = \frac{k^2 - x^2 + x(x - 1) + (x - 1)}{x - 1} = \frac{k^2 - 1}{x - 1}
   \]

5. We can further factorize \( \frac{k^2 - 1}{x - 1} \) as:
   \[
   \frac{k^2 - 1}{x - 1} = \frac{(k - 1)(k + 1)}{x - 1} = \frac{(k - 1)}{b_1} \cdot \frac{(k + 1)}{b_2}
   \]
   Since \( b_1 \mid (k - x) \) and \( b_2 \mid (k + x) \), both \( \frac{k - 1}{b_1} \) and \( \frac{k + 1}{b_2} \) are integers.

6. We need to verify that neither \( \frac{k - 1}{b_1} \) nor \( \frac{k + 1}{b_2} \) can equal 1. Note that:
   \[
   b_1, b_2 \leq b_1 b_2 = x - 1 < k - 1
   \]
   Since \( y \) is positive, both terms \( \frac{k - 1}{b_1} \) and \( \frac{k + 1}{b_2} \) are greater than 1.

7. Therefore, \( x + y + 1 \) is a product of two integers greater than 1, which means it is a composite number.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: The natural numbers $x, y > 1$, are such that $x^2 + xy -y$ is the square of a natural number. Prove that $x + y + 1$ is a composite number.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The natural numbers $x, y > 1$, are such that $x^2 + xy -y$ is the square of a natural number. Prove that $x + y + 1$ is a composite number. -/
theorem number_theory_89288 (x y : ℕ) (hx : 1 < x) (hy : 1 < y)
    (h : ∃ n, n^2 = x^2 + x * y - y) :
    ¬Prime (x + y + 1) := by

soln_description:
Solution. First, let's investigate equation (1):

If $x \geqslant 0$ and $y \geqslant 0$, then $2 x=2 y$, i.e., in this case, the graph of equation (1) is the bisector OA of the first coordinate angle (Fig. 2).

If $x<0$ and $y \geqslant 0$, then $0=2 y$, i.e., in this case, the graph of equation (1) will be the ray $O C$.

Let $x \leqslant 0$ and $y \leqslant 0$. Then equation (1) takes the form $0=0$. This means that all points in the third coordinate angle are solutions to equation (1).

Fig. 1
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_21_8debcc8c8285c4d79a3dg-071.jpg?height=496&width=1030&top_left_y=254&top_left_x=525)

Fig. 2

Finally, let $x \geqslant 0, y \leqslant 0$. Then equation (1) transforms to $2 x=0$, i.e., $x=0$.

Thus, the solutions to equation (1) are all points in the third coordinate angle (including its sides) and the points on the bisector $O A$ of the first coordinate angle. Now, let's investigate equation (2):

If $x \geqslant 1$, then $x-1=x+|y|$, i.e., in this case, equation (2) has no solutions.

Let $x<1$. We get $1-x=x+|y|$ or $x=0.5(1-|y|)$.

Thus, the graph of equation (2) is the union of rays $D F$ and $D E$.

We find the coordinates of point $P$, where rays $O A$ and $D F$ intersect. Segment $O P$ is the bisector of angle $D O F$ of triangle $D O F$. Therefore, $D P: P F=O D: O F=1: 2$. From this, it follows that $P\left(\frac{1}{3} ; \frac{1}{3}\right)$.

Thus, the solution to the given system of equations (1) and (2) is each point on ray $E H$ and point $P\left(\frac{1}{3} ; \frac{1}{3}\right)$.
informal_statement:
3 Task 2. Solve the system of equations

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
|x|+x=|y|+y \\
|x-1|=x+|y|
\end{array}\right.
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3 Task 2. Solve the system of equations

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
|x|+x=|y|+y \\
|x-1|=x+|y|
\end{array}\right.
$$ -/
theorem algebra_217892 {x y : ℝ} (hx : abs x + x = abs y + y) (hy : abs (x - 1) = x + abs y) :
    x = 1 / 3 ∧ y = 1 / 3 := by

soln_description:
We note that $64=2^{6}$ and $512=2^{9}$.

Therefore, the equation $512^{x}=64^{240}$ can be rewritten as $\left(2^{9}\right)^{x}=\left(2^{6}\right)^{240}$ or $2^{9 x}=2^{6(240)}$.

Since the bases in this last equation are equal, then the exponents are equal, so $9 x=6(240)$ or $x=\frac{1440}{9}=160$.

ANSWER: (D)
informal_proof:
We are given the equation $512^x = 64^{240}$ and wish to find the value of $x$. The strategy is to express both sides of the equation as powers of the same base, specifically base 2.

**Step 1: Express $512^x$ as a power of 2.**

First, we establish a general property: for any natural number $n$, $512^n = 2^{9n}$. We prove this by induction on $n$.

*   **Base Case (for $n=0$):**
    We need to show $512^0 = 2^{9 \cdot 0}$.
    $512^0 = 1$ (any non-zero number raised to the power of 0 is 1).
    $2^{9 \cdot 0} = 2^0 = 1$.
    Thus, $512^0 = 2^{9 \cdot 0}$ holds.

*   **Inductive Step:**
    Assume that the property holds for some natural number $k$, i.e., $512^k = 2^{9k}$. This is our inductive hypothesis.
    We need to show that the property also holds for $k+1$, i.e., $512^{k+1} = 2^{9(k+1)}$.
    We start with the left-hand side:
    $512^{k+1} = 512^k \cdot 512$ (by the definition of exponentiation).
    By the inductive hypothesis, we can substitute $512^k = 2^{9k}$:
    $512^{k+1} = 2^{9k} \cdot 512$.
    We observe that $512 = 2^9$. Substituting this value:
    $512^{k+1} = 2^{9k} \cdot 2^9$.
    Using the rule $a^b \cdot a^c = a^{b+c}$ for exponents:
    $512^{k+1} = 2^{9k + 9}$.
    Factoring out 9 from the exponent:
    $512^{k+1} = 2^{9(k+1)}$.
    This matches the desired form, so the property holds for $k+1$.

By the principle of mathematical induction, $512^n = 2^{9n}$ for all natural numbers $n$.
Applying this for our specific variable $x$, we have:
$512^x = 2^{9x}$.

**Step 2: Express $64^{240}$ as a power of 2.**

We observe that $64$ can be expressed as a power of 2:
$64 = 2^6$.
Now substitute this into the right-hand side of the original equation:
$64^{240} = (2^6)^{240}$.
Using the exponent rule $(a^b)^c = a^{bc}$:
$64^{240} = 2^{6 \cdot 240}$.
Multiplying the exponents:
$6 \cdot 240 = 1440$.
So, we have:
$64^{240} = 2^{1440}$.

**Step 3: Substitute and equate exponents.**

Now we substitute the expressions derived in Step 1 and Step 2 back into the original equation $512^x = 64^{240}$:
$2^{9x} = 2^{1440}$.

Since the base of the exponential expressions (which is 2) is greater than 1, the exponential function $f(y) = 2^y$ is injective. This means if $2^A = 2^B$, then $A$ must be equal to $B$.
Therefore, we can equate the exponents:
$9x = 1440$.

**Step 4: Solve for $x$.**

To find $x$, we divide both sides of the equation by 9:
$x = \frac{1440}{9}$.
$x = 160$.

Thus, the value of $x$ is 160.

The final answer is $\boxed{\text{160}}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- If $512^{x}=64^{240}$, then $x$ equals
(A) 80
(B) 30
(C) 360
(D) 160
(E) 237 -/
theorem algebra_274061 (x : ℕ) (h : 512 ^ x = 64 ^ 240) : x = 160 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_274061 (x : ℕ) (h : 512 ^ x = 64 ^ 240) : x = 160 := by
  have h1 : (512 : ℕ) ^ x = 2 ^ (9 * x) := by
    have h10 : ∀ (n : ℕ), (512 : ℕ) ^ n = 2 ^ (9 * n) := by
      intro n
      induction n with
      | zero =>
        simp
      | succ n ih =>
        calc
          (512 : ℕ) ^ (n + 1) = (512 : ℕ) ^ n * 512 := by ring
          _ = (2 ^ (9 * n)) * 512 := by rw [ih]
          _ = 2 ^ (9 * n) * 2 ^ 9 := by norm_num
          _ = 2 ^ (9 * (n + 1)) := by ring_nf
    specialize h10 x
    exact h10 
  have h2 : (64 : ℕ) ^ 240 = 2 ^ 1440 := by
    norm_num
  rw [h1, h2] at h 
  have h3 : 9 * x = 1440 := by
    exact Nat.pow_right_injective (by norm_num) h 
  omega

soln_description:
4. 256.

Since $a+b+c=2$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
S= & (b c-2 b-2 c+4)(c a-2 c-2 a+4) . \\
& (a b-2 a-2 b+4) \\
= & (b-2)(c-2)(c-2)(a-2) . \\
& (a-2)(b-2) \\
= & (a-2)^{2}(b-2)^{2}(c-2)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

is a perfect square.
Also, since $a+b+c=2$ and $a, b, c$ are integers, at least one of $a, b, c$ is even.
Thus, $S$ is even.
Given $S>200$, we have
$$
S \geqslant 16^{2}=256.
$$

When $a=4, b=0, c=-2$, $S=256$.
Therefore, the minimum value of $S$ is 256.
informal_statement:
4. Integers $a, b, c$ satisfy $a+b+c=2$, and
$$
S=(2 a+b c)(2 b+c a)(2 c+a b)>200 \text {. }
$$

Then the minimum value of $S$ is $\qquad$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4. Integers $a, b, c$ satisfy $a+b+c=2$, and
$$
S=(2 a+b c)(2 b+c a)(2 c+a b)>200 \text {. }
$$

Then the minimum value of $S$ is $\qquad$. -/
theorem algebra_212499 :
    IsLeast {x | ∃ a b c : ℤ, a + b + c = 2 ∧ x = (2 * a + b * c) * (2 * b + c * a) * (2 * c + a * b) ∧ x > 200} 256 := by

soln_description:
a) We wish to find integers $a$ and $b$ such that the number of prime factors of the integers $x+a$ and $x+b$ have the same parity. This amounts to finding two sequences of 50 consecutive integers $a+1, \ldots, a+50$ and $b+1, \ldots, b+50$ such that the number of prime factors of $a+1$ and $b+1$ have the same parity, the number of prime factors of $a+2$ and $b+2$ have the same parity, etc...

If we define $f(x)=0$ if the number of prime factors of $x$ is even and $f(x)=1$ if it is odd, we observe that there are only $2^{50}$ possible sequences of 0s and 1s for the sequence $f(a+1), \ldots, f(a+50)$.

Thus, among the sequences $(f(1), \ldots, f(50)); (f(51), \ldots, f(100)); \ldots; \left(f\left(2^{50}+1\right), \ldots f\left(2^{50}+50\right)\right)$, there are two equal sequences. Therefore, we have two integers $a$ and $b$ such that $(f(a+1), \ldots f(a+50))$ and $(f(b+1), \ldots, f(b+50))$ are equal. The integers $a$ and $b$ thus satisfy the condition.

b) We can be convinced, in light of the previous question, that the function $f(x)$ introduced in the previous question is not periodic from a certain rank and therefore that the integers $a$ and $b$ cannot be distinct, but we propose a rigorous reasoning:

Suppose by contradiction that $a \neq b$. We observe that $P(k(b-a)-a)=k(k+1)(b-a)^{2}$ for $k$ a sufficiently large integer so that $k(b-a)-a$ is strictly positive. The number $P(k(b-a)-a)$ therefore has an even number of prime factors if and only if $k(k+1)$ has an even number of prime factors. Since by contradiction this is the case for all sufficiently large integers $k$, this implies that $f(k)=f(k+1)$ for all sufficiently large integers $k$ and therefore that the function $f$ is constant from a certain rank. But for any prime number $p, f(p)=1$ and for any integer $k, f\left(k^{2}\right)=0$. The function is therefore not constant, hence the desired contradiction.
informal_statement:
(IMO SL 2009 N2) A strictly positive integer $N$ is said to be pretty if $N=1$ or if $N$ can be written as a product of an even number of prime factors (not necessarily distinct). For any pair $(a, b)$ of strictly positive integers, we set $P(x)=(x+a)(x+b)$.

a) Show that there exist distinct strictly positive integers $(a, b)$ such that $P(1), P(2), \ldots, P(50)$ are pretty.

b) Show that if $P(n)$ is pretty for all integers $n>0$, then $a=b$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def is_pretty (N : ℕ) := N = 1 ∨ Even (Nat.primeFactors N).card

/- (IMO SL 2009 N2) A strictly positive integer $N$ is said to be pretty if $N=1$ or if $N$ can be written as a product of an even number of prime factors (not necessarily distinct). For any pair $(a, b)$ of strictly positive integers, we set $P(x)=(x+a)(x+b)$.

a) Show that there exist distinct strictly positive integers $(a, b)$ such that $P(1), P(2), \ldots, P(50)$ are pretty.

b) Show that if $P(n)$ is pretty for all integers $n>0$, then $a=b$ -/
theorem number_theory_162377 :
    (∃ a b : ℕ, a > 0 ∧ b > 0 ∧ a ≠ b ∧ ∀ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 50, is_pretty ((i + a) * (i + b))) ∧
    (∀ a b : ℕ, a > 0 ∧ b > 0 → ∀ n > 0, is_pretty ((n + a) * (n + b)) → a = b) := by

soln_description:
$\left(\frac{1 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \cdot \ldots \cdot(2 n-1)}{2 \cdot 4 \cdot 6 \cdot \ldots \cdot 2 n}\right)^{2}<\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{3}{4} \cdot \frac{4}{5} \cdot \ldots \cdot \frac{2 n-1}{2 n} \cdot \frac{2 n}{2 n+1}=\frac{1}{2 n+1}$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_06_e0ce4a33d8b15522751eg-19.jpg?height=86&width=1378&top_left_y=114&top_left_x=14)

In the expansion of $(x+y)^{n}$ by the binomial formula of Newton, the second term turned out to be 240, the third - 720, and the fourth - 1080. Find $x, y$ and $n$.

## Solution

By the condition $n x^{n-1} y=240, n(n-1) x^{n-2} y^{2}=2 \cdot 720, n(n-1)(n-2) x^{n-3} y^{3}=6 \cdot 1080$. Dividing the second equation by the first, the third by the second, and denoting

$t=y / x$, we get $(n-1) t=6,(n-2) t=4.5$. From here $t=1.5, n-1=4$. Substituting into the first equation: $5 x^{5} \cdot 1.5=240$, that is, $x=2$, and $y=3$.

## Answer

$x=2, y=3, n=5$.
informal_statement: Prove the inequality for natural $n: \frac{1 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \cdot \ldots \cdot(2 n-1)}{2 \cdot 4 \cdot 6 \cdot \ldots \cdot 2 n} \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 n+1}}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Prove the inequality for natural $n: \frac{1 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \cdot \ldots \cdot(2 n-1)}{2 \cdot 4 \cdot 6 \cdot \ldots \cdot 2 n} \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 n+1}}$. -/
theorem inequalities_191723 (n : ℕ) :
    (∏ i ∈ Finset.range n, (2 * i + 1)) / (∏ i ∈ Finset.range n, (2 * i + 2)) ≤
    1 / sqrt (2 * n + 1) := by

informal_statement:
Let $a, b, c \ge 0$ and $a + b + c = 3$. Prove that:
$$a + ab + abc \le 4$$
informal_proof:
Let $a, b, c$ be real numbers such that $a \ge 0$, $b \ge 0$, and $c \ge 0$. We are also given that their sum is $a + b + c = 3$. We want to prove the inequality $a + ab + abc \le 4$.

First, we use the given sum constraint to express $c$ in terms of $a$ and $b$. From $a + b + c = 3$, we can deduce that $c = 3 - a - b$.

Next, we substitute this expression for $c$ into the target inequality. The inequality $a + ab + abc \le 4$ becomes:
$$a + ab + ab(3 - a - b) \le 4$$
Expanding the terms, this is equivalent to:
$$a + ab + 3ab - a^2b - ab^2 \le 4$$
$$a + 4ab - a^2b - ab^2 \le 4$$

To prove this final inequality, we invoke a non-linear arithmetic solver. This solver takes into account all the given conditions:
1.  $a \ge 0$
2.  $b \ge 0$
3.  The non-negativity of $c$, which implies $3 - a - b \ge 0$.
4.  Consequently, we also have $ab \ge 0$, $a(3-a-b) \ge 0$ (i.e., $ac \ge 0$), and $b(3-a-b) \ge 0$ (i.e., $bc \ge 0$).
5.  Furthermore, the solver uses the universal truth that the square of any real number is non-negative. Specifically, it considers the following non-negative terms:
    *   $(a-1)^2 \ge 0$
    *   $(b-1)^2 \ge 0$
    *   $(a+b-1)^2 \ge 0$
    *   $(a-b)^2 \ge 0$
    *   $(a+b-2)^2 \ge 0$

By algebraically combining these fundamental non-negativity facts with the derived constraints, the non-linear arithmetic solver is able to verify that the inequality $a + 4ab - a^2b - ab^2 \le 4$ holds true under the given conditions. This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $a, b, c \ge 0$ and $a + b + c = 3$. Prove that:
$$a + ab + abc \le 4$$ -/
theorem inequalities_6916
    (a b c : ℝ)
    (ha : 0 ≤ a)
    (hb : 0 ≤ b)
    (hc : 0 ≤ c)
    (hsum : a + b + c = 3) :
    a + a * b + a * b * c ≤ 4 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_6916
    (a b c : ℝ)
    (ha : 0 ≤ a)
    (hb : 0 ≤ b)
    (hc : 0 ≤ c)
    (hsum : a + b + c = 3) :
    a + a * b + a * b * c ≤ 4 := by

  have ha' : c = 3 - a - b := by linarith
  
  rw [ha']
  
  nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - 1), sq_nonneg (b - 1), sq_nonneg (a + b - 1), sq_nonneg (a * b), sq_nonneg (a - b), sq_nonneg (a + b - 2), sq_nonneg (a * (3 - a - b)), sq_nonneg (b * (3 - a - b)), mul_nonneg ha hb, mul_nonneg hb (show 0 ≤ (3 - a - b) by nlinarith)]

soln_description: Solution. For example: 1) $100=222: 2-22: 2, \quad$ 2) $100=(2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2+2) \cdot(2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2+2)$. There are $u$ other solutions.
informal_statement: 1. Vasya can get the number 100 using ten twos, parentheses, and arithmetic operation signs: $100=(22: 2-2: 2) \cdot(22: 2-2: 2)$. Improve his result: use fewer twos and get the number 100. (It is sufficient to provide one example).
informal_proof:
To prove the existence of numbers \(x\) and \(y\) such that \(x = 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 + 2\), \(y = 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 + 2\), and \(100 = x \cdot y\), we will provide explicit values for \(x\) and \(y\) and then verify that they satisfy all the given conditions.

Let us define \(x\) and \(y\) as follows:
Let \(x = 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 + 2\).
Let \(y = 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 + 2\).

Now, we must verify the three conditions:

1.  **Verification of \(x = 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 + 2\)**:
    By our chosen definition, \(x\) is precisely \(2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 + 2\). Thus, the equality \(x = 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 + 2\) holds by definition and reflexivity.

2.  **Verification of \(y = 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 + 2\)**:
    Similarly, by our chosen definition, \(y\) is precisely \(2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 + 2\). Thus, the equality \(y = 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 + 2\) holds by definition and reflexivity.

3.  **Verification of \(100 = x \cdot y\)**:
    Substitute the defined values of \(x\) and \(y\) into the equation:
    \[
    x \cdot y = (2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 + 2) \cdot (2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 + 2)
    \]
    First, evaluate the expression inside the parentheses:
    \[
    2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 + 2 = 8 + 2 = 10
    \]
    Now, substitute this result back into the product:
    \[
    x \cdot y = 10 \cdot 10 = 100
    \]
    Therefore, we have shown that \(100 = x \cdot y\).

Since we have found specific values for \(x\) and \(y\) that satisfy all three conditions, we have proven the existence of such \(x\) and \(y\). Specifically, \(x = 10\) and \(y = 10\) satisfy the statement \(x = 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 + 2 \land y = 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 + 2 \land 100 = x \cdot y\).

This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Vasya can get the number 100 using ten twos, parentheses, and arithmetic operation signs: $100=(22: 2-2: 2) \cdot(22: 2-2: 2)$. Improve his result: use fewer twos and get the number 100. (It is sufficient to provide one example). -/
theorem algebra_114361 : ∃ x y, x = 2 * 2 * 2 + 2 ∧ y = 2 * 2 * 2 + 2 ∧ 100 = x * y := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_114361 : ∃ x y, x = 2 * 2 * 2 + 2 ∧ y = 2 * 2 * 2 + 2 ∧ 100 = x * y := by 
  refine ⟨2 * 2 * 2 + 2, 2 * 2 * 2 + 2, by rfl, by rfl, by norm_num⟩

informal_statement: Express $\frac{31}{2\cdot5^6}$ as a terminating decimal.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Express $\frac{31}{2\cdot5^6}$ as a terminating decimal. -/
theorem number_theory_11273 : (31 / (2 * 5 ^ 6)) = 0.000992 := by

soln_description:
## 1. Version for Grade 5 & Grade 6

To begin with, we note that a hussel number can only contain the digits 2, 4, 6, and 8. Indeed, if we arrange the digits in any random order, we get an even number (divisible by 12) due to property (3). Since the last digit of an even number is always even, it must be 2, 4, 6, or 8 because 0 is not included due to property (1). Since we can place any digit at the end, this applies to every digit of a hussel number.

Next, we note that a hussel number can only contain the digits 4 and 8. Suppose a hussel number has the digit 2. By suitably rearranging the digits, we get a number where the last digit is 2. The last two digits of this number are then 22, 42, 62, or 82. The number is then not divisible by 4 (and thus not divisible by 12), contradicting property (3). Similarly, a hussel number cannot have the digit 6 because a number ending in 26, 46, 66, or 86 is not divisible by 4.

Since a hussel number is divisible by 3 (because it is divisible by 12), the sum of its digits is also divisible by 3. If we have \( k \) eights and \( 10 - k \) fours, then the sum of the digits is \( 8k + 4(10 - k) = 40 + 4k = 36 + 4(k + 1) \). This is divisible by 3 if \( k + 1 \) is divisible by 3, i.e., if \( k = 2 \), \( k = 5 \), or \( k = 8 \). We see that a hussel number of ten digits must consist of 2 eights and 8 fours, 5 eights and 5 fours, or 8 eights and 2 fours. Note that these numbers all satisfy properties (1) and (3). We only need to check which of these numbers are divisible by 11 (property (2)).

We use the 11-criterion: a number is divisible by 11 if the alternating sum of its digits is divisible by 11. By alternating sum, we mean that we take the digits alternately with a plus sign and a minus sign. In our case, all digits are either 4 or 8, so the alternating sum must be divisible by \( 4 \times 11 = 44 \). Since the alternating sum can never be greater than \( 8 + 8 + 8 + 8 + 8 - 4 - 4 - 4 - 4 - 4 = 20 \) (and never less than -20), the alternating sum must be 0. In other words, the sum of the five digits in the odd positions must be equal to the sum of the five digits in the even positions. This means that the number of eights in the odd positions must be equal to the number of eights in the even positions. We consider the three cases we previously distinguished:

- Suppose there are 2 eights in total. The only requirement now is that there is exactly 1 eight in an odd position and 1 eight in an even position. There are thus \( 5 \times 5 = 25 \) possibilities.
- Suppose there are 5 eights in total. Since we cannot divide the eights into two equal quantities, there are no solutions in this case.
- Suppose there are 8 eights in total. The only requirement now is that there are exactly 4 eights in the odd positions and 4 eights in the even positions. In other words, 1 odd position is a four and 1 even position is a four. There are again \( 5 \times 5 = 25 \) possibilities.

We conclude that there are a total of \( 25 + 25 = 50 \) ten-digit hussel numbers.
informal_statement:
1. Call a positive integer a hussel number if:

(1) All digits are not equal to 0.

(2) The number is divisible by 11.

(3) The number is divisible by 12. If you rearrange the digits in any other random order, you always get a number that is divisible by 12.

How many 10-digit hussel numbers are there?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def is_hussel (n : ℕ) : Prop :=
  (Nat.digits 10 n).all (fun d => d ≠ 0) ∧
  11 ∣ n ∧ 12 ∣ n ∧
  (Nat.digits 10 n).permutations.all (fun p => 12 ∣ Nat.ofDigits 10 p)

/- 1. Call a positive integer a hussel number if:

(1) All digits are not equal to 0.

(2) The number is divisible by 11.

(3) The number is divisible by 12. If you rearrange the digits in any other random order, you always get a number that is divisible by 12.

How many 10-digit hussel numbers are there? -/
theorem number_theory_173912 :
    Set.ncard {n | n ∈ Finset.Icc 1000000000 9999999999 ∧ is_hussel n} = 50 := by

informal_statement: In an acute triangle $ABC$, $\sin A=2\sin B\sin C$, then the minimum value of $\tan A\tan B\tan C$ is ___          ___ .
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- In an acute triangle $ABC$, $\sin A=2\sin B\sin C$, then the minimum value of $\tan A\tan B\tan C$ is ___          ___. -/
/- In an acute triangle $ABC$, $\sin A=2\sin B\sin C$, then the minimum value of $\tan A\tan B\tan C$ is ___          ___ . -/
theorem algebra_11104 (A B C : Real) (hA : A ∈ Set.Ioo 0 (Real.pi / 2)) (hB : B ∈ Set.Ioo 0 (Real.pi / 2))
    (hC : C ∈ Set.Ioo 0 (Real.pi / 2)) (hABC : A + B + C = Real.pi) (h : Real.sin A = 2 * Real.sin B * Real.sin C) :
    Real.tan A * Real.tan B * Real.tan C ≥ 8 := by

informal_statement: Determine which of the two expressions, $e^\pi$ or $\pi^e$, is larger. Provide a detailed proof, including the use of derivatives to analyze the function $f(x) = x^{\frac{1}{x}}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Determine which of the two expressions, $e^\pi$ or $\pi^e$, is larger. Provide a detailed proof, including the use of derivatives to analyze the function $f(x) = x^{\frac{1}{x}}$. -/
theorem calculus_2025 : Real.exp π > Real.pi ^ Real.exp 1 := by

soln_description:
Solution: The answer is affirmative. We construct using induction.
Take $a_{1}$ as a positive integer, such that $2 a_{1} \notin \left\{b_{n}\right\}_{n=1}^{\infty}, a_{1}>b-a$ (for example, if $b_{n_{0}}>b-a+1$, take $a_{1}^{*}=b_{n_{0}}-1$).
Assume we have taken $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{k}$ such that
$$
a_{i+1}-a_{i} \in\{\dot{a}, b\}, a_{m}+a_{l} \in \left\{b_{n}\right\}_{n=1}^{\infty}
$$
$(1 \leqslant m \leqslant k, 1 \leqslant l \leqslant k)$. Consider
( I ) $a_{1}+a_{k}+a, a_{2}+a_{k}+a, \cdots, a_{k}+a_{k}+a$, $2 a_{k}+2 a$
(II) $a_{1}+a_{k}+b, a_{2}+a_{k}+b, \cdots, a_{k}+a_{k}+b$, $2 a_{k}+2 b$.

Assume (I) contains a term $b_{u}$ from $\left\{b_{n}\right\}_{n=1}^{\infty}$, and (II) contains a term $b_{n}$ from $\left\{b_{n}\right\}_{n=1}^{\infty}$. Since
$$
2 a_{k}+2 b0$. By the induction hypothesis, we know $\dot{a}_{i}-a_{j}=c a+d b, c, d$ are non-negative integers.
Thus, $c a+d b=b-a$.
In this case, $a=0, b=(c+1) a$, which contradicts that $a$ does not divide $b$.
Case $2 b_{u}=2 a_{k}+2 a$.
In this case, $a_{k}-a_{j}=b-2 a$. By $1 \leqslant j \leqslant k$ and the induction hypothesis,
$a_{k}-a_{j}=c^{\prime} a+d^{\prime} b, c^{\prime}, d^{\prime}$ are non-negative integers.
Thus, $c^{\prime} a+d^{\prime} b=b-2 a$.
Therefore, $d^{\prime}=0, b=\left(c^{\prime}+1\right) a$, which is a contradiction.
Hence, (I) or (II) does not contain any term from $\left\{b_{n}\right\}_{n=1}^{\infty}$.
Thus, we can take $a_{k+1}=a_{k}+a$ or $a_{k}+b$ such that
$$
a_{k+1}+a_{i} \notin \left\{b_{n}\right\}_{n=1}^{\infty}, 1 \leqslant i \leqslant k+1.
$$

The proposition is proved.
informal_statement:
For given positive integers $a, b, b > a > 1$, where $a$ does not divide $b$, and a given sequence of positive integers $\left\{b_{n}\right\}_{n=1}^{\infty}$, satisfying that for all positive integers $n$, $b_{n+1} \geqslant 2 b_{n}$. Does there always exist a sequence of positive integers $\left\{a_{n}\right\}_{n=1}^{\infty}$ such that for all positive integers $n$, $a_{n+1} - a_{n} \in \{a, b\}$, and for all positive integers $m, l$ (which can be the same), $a_{m} + a_{l} \in \left\{\left.b_{n}\right|_{n=1}^{\infty}\right.$?
（Chen Yonggao provided）
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- For given positive integers $a, b, b > a > 1$, where $a$ does not divide $b$, and a given sequence of positive integers $\left\{b_{n}\right\}_{n=1}^{\infty}$, satisfying that for all positive integers $n$, $b_{n+1} \geqslant 2 b_{n}$. Does there always exist a sequence of positive integers $\left\{a_{n}\right\}_{n=1}^{\infty}$ such that for all positive integers $n$, $a_{n+1} - a_{n} \in \{a, b\}$, and for all positive integers $m, l$ (which can be the same), $a_{m} + a_{l} \in \left\{\left.b_{n}\right|_{n=1}^{\infty}\right.$?
（Chen Yonggao provided） -/
theorem number_theory_302733
    (a b : ℕ)
    (ha : 1 < a)
    (hb : a < b)
    (hdiv : ¬a ∣ b)
    (bseq : ℕ → ℕ)
    (hbseq : ∀ n, 0 < bseq n)
    (hinc : ∀ n, bseq (n + 1) ≥ 2 * bseq n) :
    ∃ aseq : ℕ → ℕ,
      (∀ n, 0 < aseq n) ∧
      (∀ n, aseq (n + 1) - aseq n = a ∨ aseq (n + 1) - aseq n = b) ∧
      (∀ m l, aseq m + aseq l ∈ Set.range bseq) := by

soln_description:
33. By the power mean inequality $\sqrt[3]{\frac{x^{3}+y^{3}+z^{3}}{3}} \geqslant \sqrt{\frac{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}{3}}$, to prove $\frac{a^{3}}{(a+b)^{3}}+$ $\frac{b^{3}}{(b+c)^{3}}+\frac{c^{3}}{(c+a)^{3}} \geqslant \frac{3}{8}$, it is sufficient to prove
$$\frac{a^{2}}{(a+b)^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}}{(b+c)^{2}}+\frac{c^{2}}{(c+a)^{2}} \geqslant \frac{3}{4}$$

Let $x=\frac{a}{a+b}, y=\frac{b}{b+c}, z=\frac{c}{c+a}$, then
$x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}+2 x z-1=\frac{a^{2}}{(a+b)^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}}{(b+c)^{2}}+\frac{c^{2}}{(c+a)^{2}}+2\left(\frac{a}{a+b}\right)\left(\frac{b}{b+c}\right)\left(\frac{c}{c+a}\right)-1=$
$\frac{a^{2}(b+c)^{2}(c+a)^{2}+b^{2}(a+b)^{2}(c+a)^{2}+c^{2}(a+b)^{2}(b+c)^{2}+2 a b c(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)-(a+b)^{2}(b+c)^{2}(c+a)^{2}}{(a+b)^{2}(b+c)^{2}(c+a)^{2}}=$
$\frac{a^{2}\left(c^{2}+a b+b c+c a\right)^{2}+b^{2}\left(a^{2}+a b+b c+c a\right)^{2}+c^{2}\left(b^{2}+a b+b c+c a\right)^{2}+2 a b((a+b+c)(a b+b c+c a)-a b c]-[(a+b+c)(a b+b c+c a)-a b]^{2}}{(a+b)^{2}(b+c)^{2}(c+a)^{2}}$
$\frac{\left(a^{24}+b^{2} a^{4}+c^{2} b^{4}\right)+2\left(a b^{2}+b^{2} c^{2}+c^{2} a^{2}\right)(b b+c c+c a)+\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)(b+b c+c a)^{2}+b b(a+b+c)(a b+c c+a)-3 a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}-(a+b+c)^{2}(b+b c+c a)^{2}}{(a+b)^{2}(b+c)^{2}(c+c)^{2}}=$
$$\frac{a^{4} b^{2}+b^{2} a^{4}+c^{2} b^{4}-3 a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}}{(a+b)^{2}(b+c)^{2}(c+a)^{2}} \geqslant 0$$

Therefore, $x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2} \geqslant 1-2 x y z$, it is sufficient to prove $x y z \leqslant \frac{1}{8}$.
By the AM-GM inequality,
$$x y z=\left(\frac{a}{a+b}\right)\left(\frac{b}{b+c}\right)\left(\frac{c}{c+a}\right) \leqslant\left(\frac{a}{2 \sqrt{a b}}\right)\left(\frac{b}{2 \sqrt{b c}}\right)\left(\frac{c}{2 \sqrt{c a}}\right)=\frac{1}{8}$$
informal_statement: 33- Given that $a, b, c$ are all positive numbers, prove: $\frac{a^{3}}{(a+b)^{3}}+\frac{b^{3}}{(b+c)^{3}}+\frac{c^{3}}{(c+a)^{3}} \geqslant \frac{3}{8}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 33- Given that $a, b, c$ are all positive numbers, prove: $\frac{a^{3}}{(a+b)^{3}}+\frac{b^{3}}{(b+c)^{3}}+\frac{c^{3}}{(c+a)^{3}} \geqslant \frac{3}{8}$. -/
theorem inequalities_601574 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    a^3 / (a + b)^3 + b^3 / (b + c)^3 + c^3 / (c + a)^3 ≥ 3 / 8 := by

soln_description: Solution. Let us assume the opposite, i.e., that $b^{2}-4 a c=k^{2}$, where $k$ is an integer. Since $b$ is an odd number, we get that $k^{2}$ and $k$ are odd numbers. Furthermore, $4ac = b^{2}-k^{2}$. The number $4ac$ is divisible by 4, but not by 8, since $a$ and $c$ are odd numbers. However, since the squares of odd numbers always leave a remainder of 1 when divided by 8, we get that the number $b^{2}-k^{2}$ is divisible by 8, which is a contradiction. Finally, from the obtained contradiction, the statement of the problem follows.
informal_statement: 1. Let $a, b, c$ be odd integers. Prove that the equation $a x^{2}+b x+c=0$ has no rational roots.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Let $a, b, c$ be odd integers. Prove that the equation $a x^{2}+b x+c=0$ has no rational roots. -/
theorem number_theory_248334 (a b c : ℤ) (ha : Odd a) (hb : Odd b) (hc : Odd c) :
    ¬∃ x : ℚ, a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c = 0 := by

soln_description:
(Solved by an anonymous student)

If $q$ is prime and $q \left\lvert\, \frac{p^{p}-1}{p-1}=\Phi_{p}(p)\right.$, then $p \mid q-1$ by cyclotomic polynomials. Clearly $p \nmid 1$, so $q \neq 2$.

Thus, $p$ and $q$ are odd, so $2 p \mid q-1$.

Thus, $\frac{p n+1}{\operatorname{pgcd}\left(p n+1, \Phi_{p}(p)\right.} \equiv p n+1 \equiv p+1(\bmod 2 p)$.

But $\left.\frac{p n+1}{\operatorname{pgcd}\left(p n+1, \Phi_{p}(p)\right.} \right\rvert\, p-1<p+1$, contradiction.
informal_statement: Let $p$ be an odd prime number and $n$ an odd natural number. Show that $pn+1$ does not divide $p^{p}-1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $p$ be an odd prime number and $n$ an odd natural number. Show that $pn+1$ does not divide $p^{p}-1$. -/
theorem number_theory_163944 (p n : ℕ) (hp : Odd p ∧ Nat.Prime p)
    (hn : Odd n) : ¬(p * n + 1 ∣ p ^ p - 1) := by

informal_statement:
Given a triangle with sides $a$, $b$, and $c$, and the expressions $w_a$, $w_b$, $w_c$, and $k_a$, $k_b$, $k_c$ defined as follows: $k_a = m_a \left(\frac{2bc}{b^2 + c^2}\right)$, where $m_a$ is the median from vertex $A$ to side $a$, and similarly for $k_b$, $k_c$, $w_a$, $w_b$, and $w_c$. Prove that:

\[(w_b^2 + w_c^2)(w_c^2 + w_a^2)(w_a^2 + w_b^2) \geq (k_b^2 + k_c^2)(k_c^2 + k_a^2)(k_a^2 + k_b^2)\]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- Given a triangle with sides $a$, $b$, and $c$, and the expressions $w_a$, $w_b$, $w_c$, and $k_a$, $k_b$, $k_c$ defined as follows: $k_a = m_a \left(\frac{2bc}{b^2 + c^2}\right)$, where $m_a$ is the median from vertex $A$ to side $a$, and similarly for $k_b$, $k_c$, $w_a$, $w_b$, and $w_c$. Prove that:

\[(w_b^2 + w_c^2)(w_c^2 + w_a^2)(w_a^2 + w_b^2) \geq (k_b^2 + k_c^2)(k_c^2 + k_a^2)(k_a^2 + k_b^2)\] -/
theorem inequalities_4158
  (a b c : ℝ)
  (ha : 0 < a)
  (hb : 0 < b)
  (hc : 0 < c)
  (h : a + b > c)
  (h' : a + c > b)
  (h'' : b + c > a)
  (w_a w_b w_c k_a k_b k_c : ℝ)
  (hw_a : w_a = (2 * b * c) / (b ^ 2 + c ^ 2))
  (hw_b : w_b = (2 * a * c) / (a ^ 2 + c ^ 2))
  (hw_c : w_c = (2 * a * b) / (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2))
  (hk_a : k_a = w_a * (2 * b * c) / (b ^ 2 + c ^ 2))
  (hk_b : k_b = w_b * (2 * a * c) / (a ^ 2 + c ^ 2))
  (hk_c : k_c = w_c * (2 * a * b) / (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2)) :
  (w_b ^ 2 + w_c ^ 2) * (w_c ^ 2 + w_a ^ 2) * (w_a ^ 2 + w_b ^ 2) ≥
  (k_b ^ 2 + k_c ^ 2) * (k_c ^ 2 + k_a ^ 2) * (k_a ^ 2 + k_b ^ 2) :=

soln_description:
1. **Define the problem and variables:**
   Let \( x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n \) be positive real numbers and define \( x_{n+1} = x_1 + x_2 + \cdots + x_n \). We need to prove the inequality:
   \[
   \sum_{k=1}^n \sqrt{x_k (x_{n+1} - x_k)} \leq \sqrt{\sum_{k=1}^n x_{n+1}(x_{n+1} - x_k)}.
   \]

2. **Apply Jensen's Inequality:**
   Jensen's Inequality states that for a convex function \( f \) and weights \( a_i \) summing to 1, we have:
   \[
   f\left(\sum_{i=1}^n a_i x_i\right) \leq \sum_{i=1}^n a_i f(x_i).
   \]
   Here, we apply it to the function \( f(x) = \sqrt{x} \), which is concave. For concave functions, the inequality is reversed:
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^n \sqrt{x_i \left(\sum_{j \neq i} x_j\right)} \leq \sqrt{n \sum_{i \neq j} x_i x_j}.
   \]

3. **Simplify the right-hand side:**
   Notice that:
   \[
   \sum_{i \neq j} x_i x_j = \sum_{i=1}^n x_i \sum_{j \neq i} x_j = \sum_{i=1}^n x_i (x_{n+1} - x_i).
   \]
   Therefore:
   \[
   \sum_{i \neq j} x_i x_j = \sum_{i=1}^n x_i (x_{n+1} - x_i).
   \]

4. **Apply the Arithmetic Mean-Geometric Mean (AM-GM) Inequality:**
   By the AM-GM Inequality, we have:
   \[
   n \sum_{i \neq j} x_i x_j \leq (n-1) \left(\sum_{i=1}^n x_i\right)^2.
   \]
   This simplifies to:
   \[
   n \sum_{i=1}^n x_i (x_{n+1} - x_i) \leq (n-1) \left(\sum_{i=1}^n x_i\right)^2.
   \]

5. **Combine the results:**
   From the above steps, we have:
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^n \sqrt{x_i \left(\sum_{j \neq i} x_j\right)} \leq \sqrt{n \sum_{i \neq j} x_i x_j} = \sqrt{n \sum_{i=1}^n x_i (x_{n+1} - x_i)}.
   \]
   Since \( x_{n+1} = \sum_{i=1}^n x_i \), we can rewrite the right-hand side as:
   \[
   \sqrt{n \sum_{i=1}^n x_i (x_{n+1} - x_i)} = \sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^n x_{n+1} (x_{n+1} - x_i)}.
   \]

6. **Conclude the proof:**
   Therefore, we have shown that:
   \[
   \sum_{k=1}^n \sqrt{x_k (x_{n+1} - x_k)} \leq \sqrt{\sum_{k=1}^n x_{n+1} (x_{n+1} - x_k)}.
   \]
   \(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
Let $ x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_n $ be positive real numbers and $ x_{n+1} = x_1 + x_2 + \cdots + x_n $. Prove that 
\[ \sum_{k=1}^n \sqrt { x_k (x_{n+1} - x_k)} \leq \sqrt { \sum_{k=1}^n x_{n+1}(x_{n+1}-x_k)}. \]
[i]Mircea Becheanu[/i]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Let $ x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_n $ be positive real numbers and $ x_{n+1} = x_1 + x_2 + \cdots + x_n $. Prove that 
\[ \sum_{k=1}^n \sqrt { x_k (x_{n+1} - x_k)} \leq \sqrt { \sum_{k=1}^n x_{n+1}(x_{n+1}-x_k)}. \]
[i]Mircea Becheanu[/i] -/
theorem inequalities_30809 (n : ℕ) (x : Fin (n + 1) → ℝ)
    (hx : ∀ i, 0 < x i) (hxn : x n = ∑ i in Finset.range n, x i) :
    ∑ k in Finset.range n, sqrt (x k * (x n - x k)) ≤
    sqrt (∑ k in Finset.range n, x n * (x n - x k)) := by

soln_description:
Solution to Exercise 16 The difficulty of this exercise lies in constructing the integer n. One might first wonder where the zeros will appear in the decimal representation of $5^{n}$. If one wants to avoid finding good rational approximations of $\log _{10} 5$ with small denominators, which is not very elegant, one should avoid looking for zeros at the beginning of the decimal representation. Moreover, it is clear that $5^{\text {n }}$ will never end in a zero. From this, one could hope to have zeros among the last digits.

The idea is to note that if $k \geqslant 1$ is fixed, then for all $n>k$, we have $5^{n} \equiv 5^{k}\left(\bmod 5^{k}\right)$. Therefore, for $5^{n}-5^{k}$ to end with k zeros, it suffices that $5^{n} \equiv 5^{k}\left(\bmod 2^{k}\right)$. Since $\varphi\left(2^{k}\right)=2^{k-1}$, this is the case as soon as $n \equiv k\left(\bmod 2^{k-1}\right)$. And in this case, provided that $5^{k}$ is written with strictly fewer than $k$ digits, there will be consecutive zeros among the last $k$ digits of $5^{n}$.

More precisely, consider the integer $\mathrm{n}=20+2^{19}=524308<10^{6}$. Clearly $5^{n} \equiv 5^{20}\left(\bmod 5^{20}\right)$, and $5^{n} \equiv 5^{20}\left(\bmod 2^{20}\right)$ since $\varphi\left(2^{20}\right)=2^{19}$. Thus, the integer $5^{n}-5^{20}$ is divisible by $10^{20}$ and therefore ends with at least 20 zeros. Since

$$
5^{10}=\frac{10^{10}}{2^{10}}<\frac{10^{10}}{10^{3}}=10^{7}
$$

we have $5^{20}<10^{14}$. Thus, $5^{20}$ has at most 14 digits, so the last 20 digits of $5^{n}=\left(5^{n}-5^{20}\right)+5^{20}$ start with a series of 6 consecutive zeros.

Graders' Comments: This problem was quite difficult and clever, and very few students submitted an attempt at a solution. However, among those who submitted a solution, a very large number provided a (nearly) complete solution. In addition to the solution $\mathrm{n}=2^{19}+20$ given in the solution, some students proved that $\mathrm{n}=2^{19}+21$ and $\boldsymbol{n}=2^{18}+20$ also work, with the same type of reasoning. Here are some general remarks:

- It turns out that a computer program (in Python, for example) can easily show that $n=3375$ is also a solution. However, there is very likely no simple mathematical proof of this fact. The few copies that mentioned this solution without justification therefore did not receive any points.
- Some students imagined that it was possible to take $n$ sufficiently small and negative so that $5^{n}$ is strictly less than $10^{-6}$, and thus starts with 6 consecutive zeros in its decimal representation. The statement was indeed imprecise in this regard, but in a number theory problem at this position in the exam, students could have deduced that only natural numbers were intended...
- Several students used the LTE lemma in the special case $p=2$ to estimate $v_{2}\left(5^{n}-1\right)$ where $n \geqslant 1$. Note that here, we indeed have $v_{2}\left(5^{n}-1\right)=2+v_{2}(n)$, but recall that for this case $p=2$, in general, if $x$ and $y$ are two odd integers, we have $v_{2}\left(x^{n}-y^{n}\right)=v_{2}(x-y)+v_{2}(x+y)+v_{2}(\mathrm{n})-1$.
- Finally, we expected students to justify precisely the inequalities invoked concerning the powers of 2, 5, or 10 used. In particular, all students who clearly used their calculator to see, for example, that $5^{20}$ has at most 14 digits lost a point.
informal_statement: Exercise 16. Show that there exists an integer $n<10^{6}$ such that the decimal representation of $5^{n}$ contains at least 6 consecutive zeros.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Exercise 16. Show that there exists an integer $n<10^{6}$ such that the decimal representation of $5^{n}$ contains at least 6 consecutive zeros. -/
theorem number_theory_293315 :
    ∃ n : ℕ, n < 10 ^ 6 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 (5 ^ n)).length ≥ 6 ∧
      ∃ i : ℕ, ∀ j ∈ Finset.range 6, (Nat.digits 10 (5 ^ n))[i + j]! = 0 := by

soln_description:
We will prove by induction that $n$ parabolas of the specified type can divide the plane into no more than $n^{2}+1$ parts.

Base case. One parabola divides the plane into $2=1^{2}+1$ parts.

Inductive step. The $n$-th parabola intersects each of the others at no more than two points. These intersection points, of which there are $m \leq 2 n-2$, divide it into $m+1$ segments. Each such segment divides one of the "old" parts of the plane into two, so the number of parts increases by no more than $2 n-1$. By the inductive hypothesis, the number of parts divided by $n$ parabolas does not exceed $2 n-1+(n-1)^{2}+1=n^{2}+1$.

Now let's construct a partition of the plane by 100 parabolas into $100^{2}+1$ parts. Consider the parabolas $y=a_{n} x^{2}-n$. Here, we take $a_{1}=1$,

and the other $a_{n}>0$ will be constructed inductively so that the absolute value of the abscissas of the points of intersection of the $n$-th parabola with the x-axis is less than the absolute values of the abscissas of the points of intersection of all previous parabolas with each other and with the x-axis. Then, obviously, each pair of parabolas intersects at two points below the x-axis, and no three intersect at the same point. From the previous reasoning, it follows that the number of parts of the partition will be maximal.

## Answer

Into 10001 parts.
informal_statement:
$\underline{\text { Vasiliev N.B. }}$

How many maximum parts can the coordinate plane xOy be divided into by the graphs of 100 quadratic trinomials of the form

$y=a_{n} X^{2}+b_{n} x+c_{n}(n=1,2, \ldots, 100) ?$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $\underline{\text { Vasiliev N.B. }}$

How many maximum parts can the coordinate plane xOy be divided into by the graphs of 100 quadratic trinomials of the form

$y=a_{n} X^{2}+b_{n} x+c_{n}(n=1,2, \ldots, 100) ?$ -/
theorem algebra_211932 (a b c : ℕ → ℝ) (ha : ∀ n, a n ≠ 0) :
    Set.ncard {x | ∃ n, y = a n * x ^ 2 + b n * x + c n} ≤ 10001 := by

soln_description:
6. Given $n=a^{2}+b$, and $a(a>1)$ is a factor of $n$, it follows that $a$ is a factor of $b$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Let } b=m a\left(m>1, m \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right) . \text { Then } \\
n=a^{2}+m a=a(a+m) \\
\Rightarrow(a+m) \mid n .
\end{array}
$$

Now we prove: $a<a+m<b$.
If $a+m \geqslant b$, then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a+m \geqslant m a \\
\Leftrightarrow a m-a-m+1 \leqslant 1 \\
\Leftrightarrow(a-1)(m-1) \leqslant 1 .
\end{array}
$$

The above inequality holds only when $a=m=2$, in which case, $b=4$, but $n=2 \times 4=8<10$, which contradicts the given condition. Therefore, $a+m$ is a factor of $n$, and lies between $a$ and $b$.

There exist $n$ that satisfy the above relationship. For example, $n=48=6^{2}+12$ has a factor 8, which lies between 6 and 12.
informal_statement: 6. Given a positive integer $n>10$, and $n$ has two distinct positive divisors $a$ and $b$, satisfying $n=a^{2}+b$. Prove: there is at least one more divisor of $n$ between $a$ and $b$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6. Given a positive integer $n>10$, and $n$ has two distinct positive divisors $a$ and $b$, satisfying $n=a^{2}+b$. Prove: there is at least one more divisor of $n$ between $a$ and $b$. -/
theorem number_theory_278904 {n : ℕ} (hn : n > 10) (a b : ℕ)
    (ha : a ∣ n) (hb : b ∣ n) (hdiv : a ≠ b) (h : n = a^2 + b) :
    ∃ d, d ∣ n ∧ a < d ∧ d < b := by

soln_description: Solution. Since the values of the quadratic trinomial $a x^{2}+b x+c$ are negative for all $x$, its leading coefficient and discriminant are negative: $a<0$ and $b^{2}-4ac<0$. If $b>0$, then the required inequality is obvious, since its left side is negative, and the right side is positive. Let $b \leqslant 0$. Then we will check the inequality $b>c+a$. For this, it is enough to understand that $b^{2}<(a+c)^{2}$. The latter is obvious, since $b^{2}<4 a c \leqslant(a+c)^{2}$.
informal_statement: 2. The values of the quadratic trinomial $a x^{2}+b x+c$ are negative for all $x$. Prove that $\frac{b}{a}<\frac{c}{a}+1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. The values of the quadratic trinomial $a x^{2}+b x+c$ are negative for all $x$. Prove that $\frac{b}{a}<\frac{c}{a}+1$. -/
theorem algebra_224627 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : a ≠ 0) (h : ∀ x : ℝ, a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c < 0) :
    b / a < c / a + 1 := by

soln_description:
1. **Initial Assumptions and Conditions**:
   We are given the function \( f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \) with the conditions:
   \[
   \begin{cases}
   f(x+24) \le f(x) + 24 \\
   f(x+77) \ge f(x) + 77
   \end{cases}
   \quad \text{for all } x \in \mathbb{R}
   \]

2. **Verification of \( f(x+1) = f(x) + 1 \)**:
   If \( f(x+1) = f(x) + 1 \) holds for all \( x \in \mathbb{R} \), then:
   \[
   f(x+24) = f(x) + 24 \quad \text{and} \quad f(x+77) = f(x) + 77
   \]
   Clearly, these satisfy the given conditions:
   \[
   f(x+24) = f(x) + 24 \le f(x) + 24
   \]
   \[
   f(x+77) = f(x) + 77 \ge f(x) + 77
   \]

3. **Induction to Generalize Conditions**:
   We use induction to show that:
   \[
   f(x + 24k) \le f(x) + 24k \quad \text{and} \quad f(x + 77k) \ge f(x) + 77k
   \]
   for any nonnegative integer \( k \).

   **Base Case**:
   For \( k = 1 \):
   \[
   f(x + 24) \le f(x) + 24 \quad \text{and} \quad f(x + 77) \ge f(x) + 77
   \]
   These are given by the problem.

   **Inductive Step**:
   Assume the statements hold for some \( k \). Then for \( k+1 \):
   \[
   f(x + 24(k+1)) = f(x + 24k + 24) \le f(x + 24k) + 24 \le f(x) + 24k + 24 = f(x) + 24(k+1)
   \]
   \[
   f(x + 77(k+1)) = f(x + 77k + 77) \ge f(x + 77k) + 77 \ge f(x) + 77k + 77 = f(x) + 77(k+1)
   \]
   Thus, by induction, the statements hold for all nonnegative integers \( k \).

4. **Deriving \( f(x+1) \ge f(x) + 1 \)**:
   Using the results from the induction:
   \[
   f(x + 385) = f(x + 24 \cdot 16 + 1) = f(x + 77 \cdot 5) \ge f(x) + 385
   \]
   This implies:
   \[
   f(x + 1) + 384 \ge f(x + 385) \ge f(x) + 385
   \]
   Simplifying, we get:
   \[
   f(x + 1) \ge f(x) + 1
   \]

5. **Contradiction and Conclusion**:
   Suppose, for the sake of contradiction, that \( f(x+1) > f(x) + 1 \). This would generalize to:
   \[
   f(x + k) > f(x) + k \quad \text{for all } k \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}
   \]
   However, this implies:
   \[
   f(x + 24) > f(x) + 24
   \]
   which contradicts the given condition \( f(x + 24) \le f(x) + 24 \). Therefore, our assumption is false, and we must have:
   \[
   f(x + 1) = f(x) + 1
   \]

Thus, we conclude that \( f(x + 1) = f(x) + 1 \) is the only solution.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
A function $f:\mathbb{R}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}$ satisfies the conditions
\[\begin{cases}f(x+24)\le f(x)+24\\ f(x+77)\ge f(x)+77\end{cases}\quad\text{for all}\ x\in\mathbb{R}\]
Prove that $f(x+1)=f(x)+1$ for all real $x$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- A function $f:\mathbb{R}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}$ satisfies the conditions
\[\begin{cases}f(x+24)\le f(x)+24\\ f(x+77)\ge f(x)+77\end{cases}\quad\text{for all}\ x\in\mathbb{R}\]
Prove that $f(x+1)=f(x)+1$ for all real $x$. -/
theorem calculus_86890 {f : ℝ → ℝ} (h1 : ∀ x, f (x + 24) ≤ f x + 24)
    (h2 : ∀ x, f (x + 77) ≥ f x + 77) :
    ∀ x, f (x + 1) = f x + 1 := by

soln_description:
## Solution.

Since the base of the logarithm depends on $x$, we need to consider the cases $x^{2}-4>1$ and $0<x^{2}-4<1$.

For the first case, if $x^{2}-4>1$, then $x \in\langle-\infty,-\sqrt{5}\rangle \cup\langle\sqrt{5},+\infty\rangle$. ( $\star$ )

The expression under the root must be non-negative, i.e., $\log _{x^{2}-4}\left(x^{2}-4 x+3\right) \geqslant 0$, or $x^{2}-4 x+2 \geqslant 0$, from which $x \in\langle-\infty, 2-\sqrt{2}] \cup[2+\sqrt{2},+\infty\rangle$. (**)

Finally, the logarithmic function is defined for positive values, so $x^{2}-4 x+3>0$ must hold, but this condition is satisfied as soon as ( $\star \star$ ) holds. Therefore, the solution of the first case is the intersection of conditions $(\star)$ and $(\star \star)$, which is $x \in\langle-\infty,-\sqrt{5}\rangle \cup[2+\sqrt{2},+\infty\rangle$.

Second case.

Now, $0<x^{2}-4<1$, then $x^{2}-4 x+3>0$, i.e., $x \in\langle-\infty, 1\rangle \cup\langle 3,+\infty\rangle .(\triangle \triangle)$

Furthermore, the expression under the root must be non-negative, so $\log _{x^{2}-4}\left(x^{2}-4 x+3\right) \geqslant 0$, i.e.,

$x^{2}-4 x+2 \leqslant 0$. The solution of this inequality is $x \in[2-\sqrt{2}, 2+\sqrt{2}]$. $(\triangle \triangle \triangle)$

The intersection of conditions $(\triangle),(\triangle \triangle)$, and $(\triangle \triangle \triangle)$ is empty, so the solution of the second case is the empty set.

Therefore, the domain of the function is $\mathcal{D}_{f}=\langle-\infty,-\sqrt{5}\rangle \cup[2+\sqrt{2},+\infty\rangle$.
informal_statement:
## Task B-4.2.

Determine the natural domain of the function $f(x)=\sqrt{\log _{x^{2}-4}\left(x^{2}-4 x+3\right)}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- ## Task B-4.2.

Determine the natural domain of the function $f(x)=\sqrt{\log _{x^{2}-4}\left(x^{2}-4 x+3\right)}$. -/
theorem algebra_234084 (f : ℝ → ℝ)
  (h₀ : ∀ x, f x = sqrt (logb (x^2 - 4) (x^2 - 4 * x + 3))) :
  {x | x^2 - 4 * x + 3 > 0 ∧ x^2 - 4 > 0} = {x | x < -sqrt 5 ∨ x ≥ 2 + sqrt 2} := by

soln_description:
$$
\begin{aligned}
& 10 x=5.123412341234123412341234123412341234 \ldots \text { and } \\
& 100000 x=51234.12341234123412341234123412341234 \ldots
\end{aligned}
$$

So $100000 x-10 x=99990 x=51229$ and finally:

$$
x=\frac{51229}{99990}
$$

which is irreducible. This method generalizes easily and shows that any number with a periodic decimal expansion can be written as a fraction. Conversely, in the decimal expansion calculation, there are only a finite number of remainders, and thus the decimal expansion of a fraction is necessarily periodic.
informal_statement:
Write in the form of a fraction (if possible) the number:

$$
x=0,5123412341234123412341234123412341234 \ldots
$$

Can you generalize this method to all real numbers with a periodic decimal expansion? And conversely
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Write in the form of a fraction (if possible) the number:

$$
x=0,5123412341234123412341234123412341234 \ldots
$$

Can you generalize this method to all real numbers with a periodic decimal expansion? And conversely -/
theorem algebra_139174 {x : ℝ} (hx : x = 51234 / 99990) :
    x = 51229 / 99990 := by

informal_statement: Find four-thirds of $\frac{9}{2}$.
informal_proof:
We are asked to find the value of the expression \( (4/3) \times (9/2) \).

To compute this product, we apply the standard rule for multiplying fractions, which states that \( \frac{a}{b} \times \frac{c}{d} = \frac{a \times c}{b \times d} \).

Applying this rule to our expression:
1.  Multiply the numerators: \( 4 \times 9 = 36 \).
2.  Multiply the denominators: \( 3 \times 2 = 6 \).

This gives us the fraction \( \frac{36}{6} \).

Finally, we simplify this fraction:
\( \frac{36}{6} = 6 \).

Therefore, \( (4/3) \times (9/2) = 6 \).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find four-thirds of $\frac{9}{2}$. -/
theorem algebra_11786 : (4 / 3 : ℝ) * (9 / 2) = 6 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_11786 : (4 / 3 : ℝ) * (9 / 2) = 6 := by
  norm_num

soln_description:
5. E.

Since the polynomial
$$
x^{2}-3 x+2=(x-1)(x-2)
$$

has roots 1 and 2, therefore, $x^{2}-5 x+k$ has one root as $x=1$ or $x=2$.
When $x=1$, $k_{1}=4$;
When $x=2$, $k_{2}=6$.
Thus, $k_{1}+k_{2}=10$.
informal_statement:
5. If the polynomials $x^{2}-3 x+2$ and $x^{2}-5 x+k$ have a common root, then the sum of all possible real values of $k$ is ( ).
(A) 3
(B) 4
(C) 5
(D) 6
(E) 10
informal_proof:
To find the sum of all possible real values of \(k\) such that the polynomials \(x^2 - 3x + 2\) and \(x^2 - 5x + k\) share a common root, we proceed in two main steps: first, identify the set of all such \(k\) values, and then sum them.

**Step 1: Identifying the set of possible values for \(k\)**
Let \(S\) be the set of all real numbers \(k\) for which there exists a real number \(x\) satisfying both \(x^2 - 3x + 2 = 0\) and \(x^2 - 5x + k = 0\). We will prove that \(S = \{4, 6\}\). This requires showing two directions:

**Part 1: If \(k \in S\), then \(k=4\) or \(k=6\).**
Assume that \(k \in S\). By definition, there exists a real number \(x\) such that:
1.  \(x^2 - 3x + 2 = 0\)
2.  \(x^2 - 5x + k = 0\)

First, we factor the quadratic equation (1):
\(x^2 - 3x + 2 = (x - 1)(x - 2)\)
So, equation (1) becomes \((x - 1)(x - 2) = 0\). By the zero product property, this implies that \(x - 1 = 0\) or \(x - 2 = 0\). Thus, the common root \(x\) must be either \(1\) or \(2\).

We consider these two possibilities for \(x\):

*   **Case 1: \(x = 1\)**
    Substitute \(x=1\) into equation (2):
    \(1^2 - 5(1) + k = 0\)
    \(1 - 5 + k = 0\)
    \(-4 + k = 0\)
    Therefore, \(k = 4\).

*   **Case 2: \(x = 2\)**
    Substitute \(x=2\) into equation (2):
    \(2^2 - 5(2) + k = 0\)
    \(4 - 10 + k = 0\)
    \(-6 + k = 0\)
    Therefore, \(k = 6\).

Combining these cases, if there is a common root \(x\), then \(k\) must be either \(4\) or \(6\). This shows that \(S \subseteq \{4, 6\}\).

**Part 2: If \(k=4\) or \(k=6\), then \(k \in S\).**
We need to show that if \(k\) is \(4\) or \(6\), then there exists a common root \(x\) for the two polynomials.

*   **Case 1: \(k = 4\)**
    We need to find an \(x\) such that \(x^2 - 3x + 2 = 0\) and \(x^2 - 5x + 4 = 0\).
    Let's choose \(x = 1\).
    For the first polynomial: \(1^2 - 3(1) + 2 = 1 - 3 + 2 = 0\). This holds.
    For the second polynomial: \(1^2 - 5(1) + 4 = 1 - 5 + 4 = 0\). This also holds.
    Thus, when \(k=4\), \(x=1\) is a common root, so \(4 \in S\).

*   **Case 2: \(k = 6\)**
    We need to find an \(x\) such that \(x^2 - 3x + 2 = 0\) and \(x^2 - 5x + 6 = 0\).
    Let's choose \(x = 2\).
    For the first polynomial: \(2^2 - 3(2) + 2 = 4 - 6 + 2 = 0\). This holds.
    For the second polynomial: \(2^2 - 5(2) + 6 = 4 - 10 + 6 = 0\). This also holds.
    Thus, when \(k=6\), \(x=2\) is a common root, so \(6 \in S\).

Since both \(4\) and \(6\) are in \(S\), we have \(\{4, 6\} \subseteq S\).
From Part 1 and Part 2, we conclude that \(S = \{4, 6\}\).

**Step 2: Computing the sum of all possible values of \(k\)**
Now that we have identified the set of all possible real values of \(k\) as \(\{4, 6\}\), we need to compute their sum. The problem asks for the sum of elements in this set, which is denoted by a finite sum.
\[
\sum_{k \in \{k : \mathbb{R} \mid \exists x, x^2 - 3x + 2 = 0 \land x^2 - 5x + k = 0\}} k
\]
Using our finding from Step 1, this sum is equivalent to:
\[
\sum_{k \in \{4, 6\}} k
\]
Since \(4\) and \(6\) are distinct elements, this sum is simply \(4 + 6\).
Calculating the sum:
\(4 + 6 = 10\)

Therefore, the sum of all possible real values of \(k\) is \(10\).

The final answer is \(\boxed{10}\).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5. If the polynomials $x^{2}-3 x+2$ and $x^{2}-5 x+k$ have a common root, then the sum of all possible real values of $k$ is ( ).
(A) 3
(B) 4
(C) 5
(D) 6
(E) 10 -/
theorem algebra_323419 : ∑ᶠ k ∈ {k : ℝ | ∃ x, x^2 - 3 * x + 2 = 0 ∧ x^2 - 5 * x + k = 0}, k = 10 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_323419 : ∑ᶠ k ∈ {k : ℝ | ∃ x, x^2 - 3 * x + 2 = 0 ∧ x^2 - 5 * x + k = 0}, k = 10 := by
  have h1 : {k : ℝ | ∃ x, x^2 - 3 * x + 2 = 0 ∧ x^2 - 5 * x + k = 0} = {4, 6} := by
    ext k
    simp only [Set.mem_setOf_eq, Set.mem_insert_iff, Set.mem_singleton_iff]
    constructor
    · -- If k is in the set, then k = 4 or 6
      intro hk
      rcases hk with ⟨x, hx1, hx2⟩
      have h1 : x^2 - 3 * x + 2 = 0 := hx1
      have h2 : x^2 - 5 * x + k = 0 := hx2
      have h3 : (x - 1) * (x - 2) = 0 := by linarith
      cases' (mul_eq_zero.mp h3) with h4 h5
      · -- Case x = 1
        have hx1_eq : x = 1 := by linarith
        rw [hx1_eq] at h2
        have hk_eq_4 : k = 4 := by linarith
        left
        linarith
      · -- Case x = 2
        have hx2_eq : x = 2 := by linarith
        rw [hx2_eq] at h2
        have hk_eq_6 : k = 6 := by linarith
        right
        linarith
    · -- If k = 4 or 6, then k is in the set
      rintro (hk4 | hk6)
      · -- k = 4
        rw [hk4]
        use 1
        constructor
        · norm_num
        · norm_num
      · -- k = 6
        rw [hk6]
        use 2
        constructor
        · norm_num
        · norm_num
  rw [h1]
  rw [finsum_mem_pair]
  all_goals norm_num

soln_description:
1.27. Let $x_{1}$ be a common root of the given equations. Subtracting one equation from the other, we get $\left(p_{1}-p_{2}\right) x_{1}=q_{2}-q_{1}$. If $p_{1}=p_{2}$, then $q_{1}=q_{2}$. If $p_{1} \neq p_{2}$, then $x_{1}=\frac{q_{2}-q_{1}}{p_{1}-p_{2}}$. Substituting this expression for $x_{1}$ into either of the two quadratic equations, we obtain the required relation. If $p_{1}=p_{2}$ and $q_{1}=q_{2}$, this relation also holds.

Conversely, let $\left(q_{2}-q_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(p_{1}-p_{2}\right)\left(p_{1} q_{2}-q_{1} p_{2}\right)=0$. If $p_{1}=p_{2}$, then $q_{1}=q_{2}$; in this case, the equations coincide, so they have a common root. If $p_{1} \neq p_{2}$, then let $x_{1}=\frac{q_{2}-q_{1}}{p_{1}-p_{2}}$. It is easy to verify that $x_{1}^{2}+p_{1} x_{1}+q_{1}=0$ and $x_{1}^{2}+p_{2} x_{1}+q_{2}=0$.
informal_statement:
1.27. Prove that the quadratic equations $x^{2}+p_{1} x+q_{1}=$ $=0$ and $x^{2}+p_{2} x+q_{2}=0$ have a common root (possibly complex) if and only if

$$
\left(q_{2}-q_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(p_{1}-p_{2}\right)\left(p_{1} q_{2}-q_{1} p_{2}\right)=0
$$

The expression $\left(q_{2}-q_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(p_{1}-p_{2}\right)\left(p_{1} q_{2}-q_{1} p_{2}\right)$ is called the resultant of the quadratic polynomials $x^{2}+p_{1} x+q_{1}$ and $x^{2}+$ $+p_{2} x+q_{2}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1.27. Prove that the quadratic equations $x^{2}+p_{1} x+q_{1}=$ $=0$ and $x^{2}+p_{2} x+q_{2}=0$ have a common root (possibly complex) if and only if

$$
\left(q_{2}-q_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(p_{1}-p_{2}\right)\left(p_{1} q_{2}-q_{1} p_{2}\right)=0
$$

The expression $\left(q_{2}-q_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(p_{1}-p_{2}\right)\left(p_{1} q_{2}-q_{1} p_{2}\right)$ is called the resultant of the quadratic polynomials $x^{2}+p_{1} x+q_{1}$ and $x^{2}+$ $+p_{2} x+q_{2}$. -/
theorem algebra_222859 {p1 p2 q1 q2 : ℂ} :
    ∃ x : ℂ, x^2 + p1 * x + q1 = 0 ∧ x^2 + p2 * x + q2 = 0 ↔
    (q2 - q1)^2 + (p1 - p2) * (p1 * q2 - q1 * p2) = 0 := by

soln_description:
$-1 . \frac{-1 \pm \sqrt{23}}{2}$.
Notice that,
$$
\begin{aligned}
f(x)= & \sqrt{(x-5)^{2}+\left(2 x^{2}-1\right)^{2}}- \\
& \sqrt{(x-3)^{2}+\left(2 x^{2}-5\right)^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Let point $P\left(x, 2 x^{2}\right), A(5,1), B(3,5)$. Then
$$
f(x)=|P A|-|P B| \leqslant|A B| .
$$

When and only when $P, A, B$ are collinear, the equality holds, at this time, $x=\frac{-1 \pm \sqrt{23}}{2}$.

import Mathlib

open Real Set

/- 1. Let the function be
$$
\begin{aligned}
f(x)= & \sqrt{4 x^{4}-3 x^{2}-10 x+26}- \\
& \sqrt{4 x^{4}-19 x^{2}-6 x+34} .
